title: First-order deformations of freely generated vertex algebras

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We solve the problem of how to classify the first-order vertex-algebraic deformations for any grading-restricted vertex algebra $V$ that is freely generated by homogeneous elements of positive weights. We approach by computing the second cohomology $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ constructed by Yi-Zhi Huang. We start with the cocycle on two generators and show that its cohomology class is completely determined by its singular part. To extend the cocycle to any pair of elements in $V$, we take a generating function approach, formulate the cocycle equation, and show that all the complementary solutions are coboundaries. Then, we use a very general procedure to construct a particular solution. The procedure applies to vertex algebras that are not freely generated. As a by-product, we show that $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)=H_{m}^{2}(V, V)$. Using these results, we explicitly determine the first-order deformations of the universal Virasoro VOA $\operatorname{Vir}_{v}$, universal affine VOA $V^{l}(\mathfrak{g})$, Heisenberg VOA $V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})$, and the universal Zamolodchikov VOA $W_{3}^{\vee}$.

## 1. INTRODUCTION

Deformation theory of algebraic structures is important in both mathematics and physics. In mathematics, deformation theory provides insights into how an algebraic structure can change continuously within a family of similar structures. By studying small perturbations or deformations, one can better understand the rigidity and flexibility of such a structure. It also aids in the classification of algebraic structures by illustrating how seemingly different structures can be interconnected through deformations. In physics, deformation quantization is a classical process in quantum physics where classical mechanics is deformed into quantum mechanics. It provides a bridge between classical and quantum descriptions.

One of the primary tools for the deformation theory of a commutative associative algebra is the second Harrison cohomology $H^{2}(A, A)$, which describes the equivalence classes of the first-order deformations of $A$ that are commutative associative algebras. Although not all firstorder deformations can be integrated into a convergent deformation of $A$, every candidate for a deformation originates from a first-order deformation. Thus, calculating $H^{2}(A, A)$ is the initial step in understanding the deformation theory of $A$.

Vertex algebras are algebraic structures formed by vertex operators satisfying certain commutativity and associativity, thus can be viewed as analogues of commutative associative algebras. Based on this analogy, using the same ideas of Harrison and Hochschild cohomologies, Yi-Zhi Huang constructed the cohomology theory of a grading-restricted vertex algebra $V$ and proved that the first-order vertex-algebraic deformations are classified by the second cohomology

$H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ (see [H1] and [H2]). As in the case of commutative associative algebras, understanding $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ is the initial step to understanding the deformation theory of vertex algebras.

Computing $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ has been a long-standing challenge, primarily due to convergence issues. In Huang's framework, the cochain complexes are defined by linear maps $\Phi: V \otimes V \rightarrow \widetilde{V}_{z_{1}, z_{2}}$ satisfying technical convergence conditions, known as the composable conditions. For the cohomology group $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$, an elements $\Phi$ in the cochain complex is $1 / 2$-composable with vertex operators, if for $v^{\prime} \in V^{\prime}, v_{1}, v_{2}, v_{3} \in V$, the series

$$
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) \Phi\left(v_{2} \otimes v_{3} ; z_{2}, z_{3}\right)\right\rangle+\left\langle v^{\prime}, \Phi\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}-\zeta\right) Y\left(v_{2}, z_{2}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1} \otimes v_{3} ; \zeta, z_{3}\right)\right\rangle
$$

and

$$
\left\langle v^{\prime}, \Phi\left(v_{1} \otimes, Y\left(v_{2}, z_{2}-\zeta\right) Y\left(v_{3}, z_{3}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1} ; z_{1}, \zeta\right)\right\rangle+\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(v_{3}, z_{3}\right) \Phi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)\right\rangle
$$

converges. Note that each summand in these expressions does not necessarily converge individually. Working with this $1 / 2$-composable condition is the primary obstacle in computing $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ and has been a persistent issue.

This paper presents a comprehensive solution to this computational problem for a gradingrestricted vertex algebra $V$ that is freely generated by a finite set $S$. We introduce a systematic algorithm that reduces the computation of a cocycle to its image on the generators. Specifically, let $\Phi$ be a cocycle representing a cohomology class in $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$. For every $u, v \in S$, we set

$$
Y_{1}(u, z) v=\Phi(u \otimes v ; z, 0)
$$

Since $Y_{1}(u, z) v$ defines a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function with pole at $z=0$, we may write

$$
Y_{1}(u, z) v=\sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}} u_{m}^{d e f} v z^{-n-1}
$$

We show that if the singular part of $Y_{1}$ satisfies the following commutator condition, namely, for $u, v, w \in S$,

$$
\left[u_{m}^{d e f}, v_{n}\right] w+\left[u_{m}, v_{n}^{d e f}\right] w=\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(u_{\alpha}^{d e f} v\right)_{m+n-\alpha} w+\left(u_{\alpha} v\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f} w\right)
$$

where $v_{n}=\operatorname{Res}_{z=0} z^{n} Y(v, z)$ is the component of the vertex operator $Y$, and $\left(u_{\alpha} v\right)_{m}^{d e f} w$ is defined via an analytic continuation process in case $u_{\alpha} v \notin S$ (see Section 3.2, Theorem 3.7), then $Y_{1}$ may be uniquely extended to a map $V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$, and for every $u, v \in V$,

$$
\Phi\left(u \otimes v ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=Y_{1}\left(u, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}
$$

is a cocycle representing a cohomology class in $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$.
The above extension process is very general and does not really need $V$ to be freely generated. We need the assumption that $V$ is freely generated for two supporting theorems. The first one (Theorem 3.4) states that with the modification by a coboundary, we may assume that for $u, v \in S, Y_{1}(u, x) v$ is completely determined by its singular parts. The second one (Theorem

3.10) shows that other than the cocycles extended from the singular parts of the $Y_{1}(u, x) v$ for $u, v \in S$, there do not exist any other nontrivial cocycles.

One of the key philosophies of proving the second theorem is to utilize the techniques of generating functions. Instead of focusing on the one-variable series $Y_{1}(u, x) v$ for $u, v \in V$, we focus on the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)
$$

for $s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$, which is the analytic continuation of the sum of the series in the parenthesis to $\left\{\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{n}: z_{i} \neq 0, z_{i} \neq z_{j}, i \neq j\right\}$. We show that the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function uniquely determines $Y_{1}(u, x) v$ for every $u, v \in V$. Then, we formulate the $n$-variable cocycle equation in terms of the matrix coefficients of the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. The cocycle equation is indeed a linear nonhomogeneous system of equations. Under the assumption that $V$ is freely generated, we show that the complementary solutions of the cocycle equations are all coboundaries. Thus, it suffices to find a particular solution. The extension process with the commutator condition also follows the same philosophy. We construct the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function explicitly and show that it is a solution of the cocycle equation.

Theorem 5.13 summarizes the main conclusions of the paper. We apply it to compute $H_{1 / 2}(V, V)$ for the following examples. If $V$ is the universal Virasoro VOA Vir $_{c}$ or the universal affine VOA $V^{l}(\mathfrak{g})$ associated with a finite-dimensional simple Lie algebra, we show that $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ is one-dimensional, corresponding to the deformation of central charge $c$, or the level $l$, respectively. If $V$ is the Heisenberg VOA $V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})$ of rank $r$, we show that $\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)=\binom{r}{3}$ when $l \neq 0$, and $\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)=3\binom{r+1}{3}$ when $l=0$. If $V$ is the universal Zamolodchikov VOA $W_{3}^{c}$, we show that $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ is one-dimensional for every $c \in \mathbb{C}$.

The proofs of Theorem 3.4 and Theorem 3.10 fail when relations exist among the basis elements. We may still use the same procedure to construct cocycles. But there might exist a nontrivial cocycle contributed by a regular $Y_{1}(u, x) v$ for $u, v \in S$. There might also exist a nontrivial cocycle contributed by a complementary solution of the cocycle equation. Nevertheless, the failure of the proofs precisely points out the direction of working out $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ when $V$ is not freely generated. We shall discuss it in the future.

As a by-product, we see that $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)=H_{\infty}^{2}(V, V)$ when $V$ is freely generated. In other words, the weaker $1 / 2$-composable condition is equivalent to the much stronger $\infty$-composable condition. So, the composable conditions assumed in the construction of cohomology theory might be naturally strengthened. In particular, it can be strengthened naturally to ensure the convergence of the operations involved in the definition of Gerstenhaber brackets of cochains, which is important for determining the integrability of first-order deformations. We shall also discuss Gerstenhaber brackets in the future.

The paper is organized as follows: Section 2 reviews the prerequisites of second cohomology and first-order deformations. Section 3 formulates the cocycles on generators, the generating functions of the cocycles, and the cocycle equation it should satisfy. We prove that the complementary solutions of the cocycle equation are all coboundaries. Sections 4 and 5 extend $Y_{1}$ from the generators to general elements in $V$ under the commutator condition. Section 6 computes the examples. We show that $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$
Acknowledgements. Both authors would like to thank Thomas Creutzig, Shashank Kanade, Andrew Linshaw and Flor Orosz Hunziker for many helpful discussions. The second author would like to thank Yi-Zhi Huang for his long-term support and the related discussions. The second author would also thank Tommy Wuxing Cai for the discussion on combinatorial identities, and Zongzhu Lin for the discussion of further possible development of the work.

# 2. Preliminaries
### 2.1. Grading-restricted vertex algebras.

Definition 2.1. A grading-restricted vertex algebra (vertex algebra hereafter) is a $\mathbb{Z}$-graded vector space $V=\coprod_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} V_{(n)}$ (graded by weights) equipped with a vertex operator map

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y: V \otimes V & \rightarrow V((x)) \\
u \otimes v & \mapsto Y(u, x) v=\sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} u_{n} v x^{-n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

and a vacuum $\mathbf{1} \in V$, satisfying the following axioms:
(1) Axioms for the grading:
(a) Lower bound condition: When $n$ is sufficiently negative, $V_{(n)}=0$.
(b) d-commutator formula: Let $\mathbf{d}_{V}: V \rightarrow V$ be defined by $\mathbf{d}_{V} v=n v$ for $v \in V_{(n)}$. Then for every $v \in V$

$$
\left[\mathbf{d}_{V}, Y_{V}(v, x)\right]=x \frac{d}{d x} Y_{V}(v, x)+Y_{V}\left(\mathbf{d}_{V} v, x\right)
$$

(2) Axioms for the vacuum:
(a) Identity property: Let $1_{V}$ be the identity operator on $V$. Then $Y_{V}(\mathbf{1}, x)=1_{V}$.
(b) Creation property: For $u \in V, Y_{V}(u, x) \mathbf{1} \in V[[x]]$ and $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} Y_{V}(u, x) \mathbf{1}=u$.
(3) $D$-derivative property and $D$-commutator formula: Let $D_{V}: V \rightarrow V$ be the operator given by

$$
D_{V} v=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{d}{d x} Y_{V}(v, x) \mathbf{1}
$$

for $v \in V$. Then for $v \in V$,

$$
\frac{d}{d x} Y_{V}(v, x)=Y_{V}\left(D_{V} v, x\right)=\left[D_{V}, Y_{V}(v, x)\right]
$$

(4) Rationality: Let $V^{\prime}=\coprod_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} V_{(n)}^{*}$ be the graded dual of $V$. For $u_{1}, u_{2}, v \in V, v^{\prime} \in V^{\prime}$, the series

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle \\
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) v\right\rangle \\
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle
\end{gathered}
$$

converge absolutely in the regions

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|z_{1}\right|>\left|z_{2}\right|>0 \\
\left|z_{2}\right|>\left|z_{1}\right|>0 \\
\left|z_{2}\right|>\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|>0
\end{gathered}
$$

respectively to a common rational function in $z_{1}, z_{2}$ with the only possible poles at $z_{1}=$ $0, z_{2}=0$ and $z_{1}=z_{2}$.

# 2.2. Freely generated vertex algebras and standard filtration. 

Definition 2.2. Let $S=\left\{a^{(1)}, \ldots, a^{(r)}\right\}$ be a subset of homogeneous elements of $V$ of positive weights.
(1) We say that $S$ strongly generates $V$ if $V$ is spanned by the elements

$$
s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{p}}^{(p)} \mathbf{1}
$$

where $p \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(p)} \in S, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{p} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$.
(2) We say that $S$ freely generates $V$ if $V$ admits a PBW-type basis

$$
a_{-m_{1}^{(1)}}^{(1)} \cdots a_{-m_{k_{1}}^{(1)}}^{(1)} \cdots a_{-m_{1}^{(r)}}^{(r)} \cdots a_{-m_{k_{r}}^{(r)}^{(r)}} \mathbf{1}
$$

where $k_{1}, \ldots, k_{r} \in \mathbb{N}, m_{1}^{(1)}, \ldots, m_{1}^{\left(k_{1}\right)}, \ldots, m_{1}^{(r)}, \ldots, m_{k_{r}}^{(r)} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$such that

$$
m_{1}^{(1)} \geq \cdots \geq m_{k_{1}}^{(1)} \geq 1, \ldots, m_{1}^{(r)} \geq \cdots \geq m_{k_{r}}^{(r)} \geq 1
$$

Remark 2.3. We note that from the results of [L1], if $V$ is strongly generated by $S$, then $V$ admits a standard filtration $V=\bigcup_{n \in \mathbb{N}} E_{N}^{S}$, with

$$
E_{N}^{S}=\operatorname{span}\left\{s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{p}}^{(p)} \mathbf{1}: \begin{array}{c}
p \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(p)} \in S, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{p} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}, \\
\operatorname{wt} s^{(1)}+\cdots+\operatorname{wt} s^{(p)} \leq N
\end{array}\right\}
$$

in the sense that for every $u \in E_{m}^{S}, v \in E_{n}^{S}$,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
u_{j} v \in E_{m+n}^{S} & \text { for } j<0 \\
u_{j} v \in E_{m+n-1}^{S}\left(\subset E_{m+n}^{S}\right) & \text { for } j \geq 0
\end{array}
$$

In this paper, we will exclusively focus on a grading-restricted vertex algebra that is freely generated by elements of positive weights.

2.3. $E$ - and $R$-notations. A lot of discussions in vertex algebras are focused on series

$$
f\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=\sum_{m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}} v_{m_{1} \cdots m_{n}} z_{1}^{-m_{1}-1} \cdots z_{n}^{-m_{n}-1}
$$

in $V\left[\left[z_{1}, z_{1}^{-1}, \ldots, z_{n}, z_{n}^{-1}\right]\right]$, such that for every $v^{\prime} \in V^{\prime}$, the complex series

$$
\left\langle v^{\prime}, f\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\right\rangle=\sum_{m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}}\left\langle v^{\prime}, v_{m_{1} \cdots m_{n}}\right\rangle z_{1}^{-m_{1}-1} \cdots z_{n}^{-m_{n}-1}
$$

converges absolutely in a certain region to a rational function with the only possible poles at $z_{i}=0(i=1, \ldots, n)$ and $z_{i}=z_{j}(1 \leq i<j \leq n)$.

Notation 2.4. We will use the notation

$$
R\left(\left\langle v^{\prime}, f\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\right\rangle\right)
$$

for the sum (or limit) of the complex series (4). We will use the notation

$$
E\left(f\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\right)
$$

to denote the corresponding $\bar{V}$-valued rational function (see [H1] and [Q2] for precise definitions), which may be viewed as the analytic continuation of the sum of the series $f\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)$ with coefficients in $V$.

Remark 2.5. It should be noted that (5) makes sense in the region

$$
\left\{\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{n}: z_{i} \neq 0,1 \leq i \leq n, z_{i} \neq z_{j}, 1 \leq i<j \leq n\right\}
$$

while (4) may converge in a much smaller region. For example, let $V$ be a vertex algebra and $v^{\prime} \in V^{\prime}, u_{1}, u_{2}, v \in V$. Then

$$
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle
$$

converges absolutely in the region $\left|z_{1}\right|>\left|z_{2}\right|>0$; the series

$$
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) v\right\rangle
$$

converges absolutely in the region $\left|z_{2}\right|>\left|z_{1}\right|>0$. Since the regions of convergence of these two series do not intersect, we cannot equate them. However, we may say that

$$
R\left(\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle\right)=R\left(\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) v\right\rangle\right)
$$

because these two series converge to a common rational function. We may also say that

$$
E\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right)=E\left(Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) v\right)
$$

when $z_{1} \neq 0, z_{2} \neq 0, z_{1} \neq z_{2}$, since these two series converge to the same $\bar{V}$-valued rational functions.

Remark 2.6. Many calculations on the $\bar{V}$-valued rational functions rely on the convergence of one single series. Once we know the convergence of one series, then we may use an argument of analytic continuation to show the convergence of many other series. For example, once we show that products of vertex operators converge, then by an analytic continuation argument using [Q1] Lemma 4.5, we may prove that the iterates of vertex operators converge (see [Q1] Theorem 4.12). The details of these analytic continuations are too lengthy to include in this manuscript. Interested readers should consult [Q1], [Q2], [HQ] and [Q3] that included many such details.
2.4. First-order deformation. Recall that a first-order deformation of a grading-restricted vertex algebra $(V, Y, \mathbf{1})$ is defined by an operator

$$
Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))
$$

such that the vector space $V^{t}=\mathbb{C}[t] /\left(t^{2}\right) \otimes_{\mathbb{C}} V$, with the vertex operator

$$
Y^{t}(u, x) v=Y(u, x) v+t Y_{1}(u, x) v
$$

and the vacuum element $\mathbf{1}$, i.e., $\left(V^{t}, Y^{t}, \mathbf{1}\right)$, forms a grading-restricted vertex algebra over the base ring $\mathbb{C}[t] /\left(t^{2}\right)$. This requires that $Y_{1}$ satisfies the following conditions.
(1) The grading of $V^{t}$ is automatically bounded below. The $\mathbf{d}$-commutator formula of $Y^{t}$ implies that the $\mathbf{d}$-commutator formula of $Y_{1}$. In particular, if we write

$$
Y_{1}(u, x) v=\sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} u_{n}^{d e f} v x^{-n-1}
$$

then

$$
\text { wt } u_{n}^{d e f} v=\text { wt } u-n-1+\text { wt } v
$$

Since generators of $V$ are of positive weights, it is also clear that for every $n \geq 0, u_{n}^{d e f} v \in$ $E_{\mathrm{wt} u+\mathrm{wt} v-1}^{\mathrm{S}}$ as in Remark 2.3.
(2) From the requirement that for every $v \in V$

$$
v=Y^{t}(\mathbf{1}, x) v=Y(\mathbf{1}, x) v+t Y_{1}(\mathbf{1}, x) v
$$

we see that for every $v \in V$,

$$
Y_{1}(\mathbf{1}, x) v=0
$$

(3) From the requirement that for every $u \in V$,

$$
e^{x D} u=Y^{t}(u, x) \mathbf{1}=Y(u, x) \mathbf{1}+t Y_{1}(u, x) \mathbf{1}
$$

we see that for every $u \in V$,

$$
Y_{1}(u, x) \mathbf{1}=0
$$

In particular, this says that $D$ is defined purely in terms of $Y$, regardless of $Y_{1}$.

(4) From the $D$-derivative-commutator formula that for every $u, v \in V$,

$$
\left[D, Y^{t}(u, x)\right] v=Y^{t}(D u, x) v=\frac{d}{d x} Y^{t}(u, x) v
$$

we see that

$$
\left[D, Y_{1}(u, x)\right] v=Y_{1}(D u, x) v=\frac{d}{d x} Y_{1}(u, x) v
$$

(5) From the requirement of associativity, i.e., for every $u_{1}, u_{2}, v \in V$, there exists $p \in \mathbb{N}$, such that

$$
\left(x_{0}+x_{2}\right)^{p} Y^{t}\left(u_{1}, x_{0}+x_{2}\right) Y^{t}\left(u_{2}, x_{2}\right) v=\left(x_{0}+x_{2}\right)^{p} Y^{t}\left(Y^{t}\left(u_{1}, x_{0}\right) u_{2}, x_{2}\right) v
$$

we see that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(x_{0}+x_{2}\right)^{p}\left(Y\left(u_{1}, x_{0}+x_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(u_{2}, x_{2}\right) v+Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, x_{0}+x_{2}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, x_{2}\right) v\right) \\
=\left(x_{0}+x_{2}\right)^{p}\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, x_{0}\right) u_{2}, x_{2}\right) v+Y_{1}\left(Y\left(u_{1}, x_{0}\right) u_{2}, x_{2}\right) v\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Equivalently, for every $v^{\prime} \in V^{\prime}, u_{1}, u_{2}, v \in V$, the series

$$
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle+\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle
$$

and

$$
\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y_{1}\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle+\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle
$$

both converge absolutely respectively in the region $\left|z_{1}\right|>\left|z_{2}\right|>0$ and $\left|z_{2}\right|>\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|>0$ to a common rational function with the only possible poles at $z_{1}=0, z_{2}=0$ and $z_{1}=z_{2}$. Note that the condition requires convergence of only the sum of the two series, not the convergence of each individual series.
(6) From the requirement of skew symmetry, i.e., for every $u, v \in V$

$$
Y^{t}(u, x) v=e^{x D} Y^{t}(v,-x) u
$$

we see that

$$
Y_{1}(u, x) v=e^{x D} Y_{1}(v,-x) u
$$

Conversely, if $Y_{1}$ satisfies (1) - (6), then with $Y^{t}=Y+t Y_{1},\left(V^{t}, Y^{t}, \mathbf{1}\right)$ forms a first-order deformation of $(V, Y, \mathbf{1})$.

Remark 2.7. Using the $R$-notation, Condition (5) of the first-order deformation can be reformulated as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R\left(\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle+\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle\right) \\
= & R\left(\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y_{1}\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle+\left\langle v^{\prime}, Y\left(Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right\rangle\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the $E$-notation, Condition (5) of the first-order deformation can be reformulated as

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v+Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right)
$$

$$
=E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v+Y\left(Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u_{2}, z_{2}\right) v\right)
$$

We call (6) the cocycle equation. the computation will be mainly based on finding solutions of (6).

Two first-order deformations $\left(V^{t}, Y^{t,(1)}\right)$ and $\left(V^{t}, Y^{t,(2)}\right)$ are equivalent, if there exists a $\mathbb{C}[t] /\left(t^{2}\right)$ linear vertex algebraic isomorphism $f^{t}: V \oplus t V=V^{t} \rightarrow V_{t}=V \oplus t V$ whose restriction on $V$ is of the form

$$
\left.f^{t}\right|_{V}=1_{V}+t f_{1}
$$

where $f_{1}: V \rightarrow V$ is a $\mathbb{C}$-linear grading-preserving map. In other words, for $u, v \in V$,

$$
f^{t}(u+t v)=u+t\left(v+f_{1}(u)\right)
$$

To emphasize, equivalent first-order deformations are isomorphic, but the converse does not necessarily hold.
2.5. 2-cocycles and 2-coboundaries. In the paper [H1] and [H2], Huang showed that the equivalence classes of first-order deformations are described by the second cohomology $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ of vertex algebras. Here we shall not give a detailed review of the definitions of 2-cocycles and 2-coboundaries, but only mention what is necessary for the current paper. For brevity, we will omit the 2-prefix and simply use cocycles and coboundaries.

Given a $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V\left[\left[x, x^{-1}\right]\right]$ satisfying (1) - (6) in Section 2.4, we may obtain a cocycle in the cohomology $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ defined by

$$
\Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=E\left(Y_{1}\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v_{2}, z_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
$$

Conversely, every element in $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ may be represented by a cocycle satisfying

$$
\Psi\left(v \otimes \mathbf{1} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=\Psi\left(\mathbf{1} \otimes v ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=0
$$

(see $[\mathrm{H} 2]$ and its addendum $[\mathrm{H} 3]$ ). We may define

$$
Y_{1}\left(v_{1}, x\right) v_{2}=\Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; x, 0\right)
$$

and see that it satisfies (1) - (6). It should be noted that the convergence requirement in (5) precisely corresponds to the $1 / 2$-composable condition defined in [H1]. It should also be noted that the cocycle $\Psi$ satisfies the following Harrison relation

$$
\Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=\Psi\left(v_{2} \otimes v_{1} ; z_{2}, z_{1}\right)
$$

and the $D$-derivative properties

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Psi\left(D v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right) & =\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{1}} \Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right) \\
\Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes D v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right) & =\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{2}} \Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
D \Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{1}}+\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{2}}\right) \Psi\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)
$$

For every homogeneous map $\phi: V \rightarrow V$ that commutes with $D$, the map

$$
\Phi(v ; z)=e^{z D} \phi(v)
$$

forms a 1-cochain that is composable with one vertex operator. Conversely, every 1-cochain composable with one vertex operator admits such an expression. Correspondingly,
$(\delta \Phi)\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=E\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) \Phi\left(v_{2} ; z_{2}\right)\right)-E\left(\Phi\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) v_{2} ; z_{2}\right)\right)+E\left(Y\left(v_{2}, z_{2}\right) \Phi\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right)\right)$
is a coboundary that has zero image in $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$. Equivalently, $\delta \Phi$ can also be expressed as
$(\delta \Phi)\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, z_{2}\right)=E\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(\phi\left(v_{2}\right), z_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)-E\left(\phi\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v_{2}, z_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)\right)+E\left(Y\left(\phi\left(v_{1}\right), z_{1}\right) Y\left(v_{2}, z_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)$.
This will be a form we frequently use in expressing a coboundary in terms of the homogenous map $\phi$. Evaluating $z_{2}=0$, we see that

$$
(\delta \Phi)\left(v_{1} \otimes v_{2} ; z_{1}, 0\right)=Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) \phi\left(v_{2}\right)-\phi\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) v_{2}\right)+Y\left(\phi\left(v_{1}\right), z_{1}\right) v_{2}
$$

Understanding the coboundary is the key in the computation of the cohomology.
Notation 2.8. We use the notation $Y_{\phi}\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) v_{2}$ for (11). The first-order deformation given by $Y_{1}=Y_{\phi}$ is equivalent to that given by $Y_{1}=0$.

Remark 2.9. Since we started with the assumption that $Y_{1}(v, x) \mathbf{1}=Y_{1}(\mathbf{1}, x) v=0$, when we determine if $Y_{1}$ is given by a coboundary $Y_{\phi}$, it is necessary to restrict that $\phi(\mathbf{1})=0$ to make sure that $Y_{\phi}$ gives a first-order (trivial) deformation.

# 3. THE COCYCLE EQUATION AND ITS COMPLEMENTARY SOLUTION 

In this section, $V$ is a grading-restricted vertex algebra that is freely generated by the set $S$. The linear map $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$ satisfies the conditions (1) - (6) in Section 2.4.
3.1. Regular part of the cocycle on the generators. We start from analyzing the regular part $Y_{1}^{+}$of a cocycle $Y_{1}$. We show that it is possible to pick a representative, such that the regular part of $Y_{1}$ is determined by its singular part $Y_{1}^{-}$.

Proposition 3.1. Fix $a, b \in S$. Then there exists a homogeneous linear map $\phi: V \rightarrow V$ (depending on $a, b$ ) such that $\phi$ commutes with $D$, and

$$
Y_{1}(a, x) b=Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a-Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b\right)+Y_{\phi}(a, x) b
$$

Proof. We first notice from the skew-symmetry of $Y_{1}$ that

$$
e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a-Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b=Y_{1}^{+}(a, x) b-e^{x D} Y_{1}^{+}(b,-x) a
$$

contains no negative powers of $x$. In particular, the singular part of $e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b$ coincides with $Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b$. To construct the homogeneous linear map $\phi$, we consider the series

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(a, x) b & =Y_{1}(a, x) b-Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b-\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a-Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b\right) \\
& =Y_{1}(a, x) b-\frac{1}{2} e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a-\frac{1}{2} Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b \\
& =Y_{1}^{+}(a, x) b-\frac{1}{2} e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a+\frac{1}{2} Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b
\end{aligned}
$$

Clearly, $\widetilde{Y}_{1}$ contains no negative powers of $x$. Moreover,

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{x D} \widetilde{Y}_{1}(b,-x) a & =e^{x D}\left(Y_{1}(b,-x) a-\frac{1}{2} e^{-x D} Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b-\frac{1}{2} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a\right) \\
& =Y_{1}(a, x) b-\frac{1}{2} Y_{1}^{-}(a, x) b-\frac{1}{2} e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a=\widetilde{Y}_{1}(a, x) b
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, since $Y_{1}$ satisfies $D$-derivative property and $D$-commutator formula, so does $Y_{1}^{+}$and $Y_{1}^{-}$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[D, \widetilde{Y}_{1}(a, x)\right] b } & =\left[D, Y_{1}(a, x)\right] b-\frac{1}{2} e^{x D} D Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a+\frac{1}{2} e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(D b,-x) a-\frac{1}{2}\left[D, Y_{1}^{-}(a, x)\right] b \\
& =\frac{d}{d x} Y_{1}(a, x)-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d}{d x}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a\right)-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d}{d x} Y_{1}^{-}(a, x)=\frac{d}{d x} \widetilde{Y}_{1}(a, x) b
\end{aligned}
$$

Using

$$
D Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) a=Y_{1}^{-}(D b,-x) a+Y_{1}^{-}(b,-x) D a
$$

we may also conclude that

$$
\left[D, \widetilde{Y}_{1}(a, x) b\right]=\widetilde{Y}_{1}(D a, x) b
$$

So $\widetilde{Y}_{1}$ also satisfies $D$-derivative property and $D$-commutator formula. Using these properties, we see that the series

$$
\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, z_{1}\right) Y\left(b, z_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}=\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, z_{1}\right) e^{z_{2}} b=e^{z_{2} D} \widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) b
$$

converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function that is indeed holomorphic everywhere. With skewsymmetry of $\widetilde{Y}_{1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left(\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, z_{1}\right) Y\left(b, z_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) & =E\left(e^{z_{2} D} \widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) b\right)=E\left(e^{z_{1} D} \widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(b,-z_{1}+z_{2}\right) a\right) \\
& =E\left(\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(b, z_{2}\right) e^{z_{1} D} a\right)=E\left(\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(b, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a, z_{1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function has no singularities, we see that as power series in $V\left[\left[x_{1}, x_{2}\right]\right]$,

$$
\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, x_{1}\right) Y\left(b, x_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}=\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(b, x_{2}\right) Y\left(a, x_{1}\right) \mathbf{1}
$$

We define $\phi: V \rightarrow V$ by specifying that

$$
\phi\left(a_{-m_{1}} b_{-m_{2}} \mathbf{1}\right)=-\operatorname{Res}_{x_{1}, x_{2}=0} x_{1}^{-m_{1}} x_{2}^{-m_{2}} \widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, x_{1}\right) Y\left(b, x_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}
$$

and for every other basis element $v$ of the form (1),

$$
\phi(v)=0
$$

Note that $\phi$ constructed in the proof annihilates $E_{\mathrm{wt}(a)+\mathrm{wt}(b)-1}^{S}$. Note also that (13) guarantees that

$$
\phi\left(a_{-m_{1}} b_{-m_{2}} \mathbf{1}\right)=\phi\left(b_{-m_{2}} a_{-m_{1}} \mathbf{1}\right)
$$

So the choice of $\phi$ does not depend on the ordering of $a, b$ in $S$.
To check that $\phi$ commutes with $D$, we use the $D$-derivative property and $D$-commutator formula,

$$
\begin{aligned}
D \widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, x_{1}\right) Y\left(b, x_{2}\right) \mathbf{1} & =\left[D, \widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, x_{1}\right)\right] Y\left(b, x_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}+\widetilde{Y}_{1}\left(a, x_{1}\right)\left[D, Y\left(b, x_{2}\right)\right] \mathbf{1} \\
& =\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}+\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{2}}\right) Y_{1}\left(a, x_{1}\right) Y\left(b, x_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking $\operatorname{Res}_{x_{1}, x_{2}=0} x_{1}^{-m_{1}} x_{2}^{-m_{2}}$, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
D \phi\left(a_{-m_{1}} b_{-m_{2}} \mathbf{1}\right) & =m_{1} \phi\left(a_{-m_{1}-1} b_{-m_{2}} \mathbf{1}\right)+m_{2} \phi\left(a_{-m_{1}} b_{-m_{2}-1} \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& =\phi\left(D a_{-m_{1}} b_{-m_{2}} \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $\phi$ commutes with $D$. To conclude the proof, we calculate that

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{\phi}(a, x) b & =Y(\phi(a), x) b-\phi(Y(a, x) b)+Y(a, x) \phi(b) \\
& =-\sum_{m \geq 1} \phi\left(a_{-m} b_{-1} \mathbf{1}\right) x^{m-1}=\widetilde{Y}_{1}(a, x) b
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, with the so-defined $\phi,(12)$ holds.
Remark 3.2. Clearly, $Y_{\phi}$ also satisfies the skew-symmetry. So for fixed $a, b \in S$, if (12) holds, then

$$
Y(b, x) a=Y_{1}^{-}(b, x) a+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}(a,-x) b-Y_{1}^{-}(b, x) a\right)+Y_{\phi}(b, x) a
$$

also holds.
Proposition 3.3. Let $S=\left\{a^{(1)}, \ldots, a^{(r)}\right\}$. Then there exists an operator $Y_{1}^{(r, r)}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$, such that
(1) $Y_{1}^{(r, r)}$ satisfies $(1)-(6)$ in Section 2.4.
(2) There exists a homogeneous linear map $\phi: V \rightarrow V$ such that

$$
Y_{1}(u, x) v=Y_{1}^{(r, r)}(u, x) v+Y_{\phi}(u, x) v
$$

for every $u, v \in V$.
(3) For every $1 \leq i, j \leq r$,

$$
Y_{1}^{(r, r)}\left(a^{(i)}, z\right) a^{(j)}=Y_{1}^{(r, r),-}\left(a^{(i)}, z\right) a^{(j)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{(r, r),-}\left(a^{(j)},-x\right) a^{(i)}-Y_{1}^{(r, r),-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}\right)
$$

Therefore, there exists a coboundary $\delta \Phi$ such that for every $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r$,
$Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z\right) a^{(j)}=Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z\right) a^{(j)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(j)},-x\right) a^{(i)}-Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}\right)+(\delta \Phi)\left(a^{(i)} \otimes a^{(j)} ; z, 0\right)$.
where $Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ is the singular part of $Y_{1}$, i.e., the part consisting only negative powers. In other words, the cohomology class of $Y_{1}$ can be represented by its singular parts.

Proof. Without loss of generality, we assume that wt $a^{(i)} \leq$ wt $a^{(j)}$ for every $1 \leq i<j \leq r$. Arrange a linear order on 2-tuple of numbers in $\{1, \ldots, r\}$ by $(1,1)<\cdots<(1, r)<(2,1)<\cdots<$ $(2, r)<\cdots<(r, 1)<\cdots<(r, r)$. We also identify $(i, r+1)$ with $(i+1,1)$ for every $i=1, \ldots, r-1$. We use Proposition 3.1 to find a homogeneous linear map $\phi_{1,1}: V \rightarrow V$ such that $Y_{1}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(1)}-Y_{\phi_{1,1}}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(1)}=Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(1)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(1)},-x\right) a^{(1)}-Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(1)}\right)$ We set $Y_{1}^{(1,1)}(u, x) v=Y_{1}(u, x) v-Y_{\phi_{1,1}}(u, x) v$. Then clearly, $Y_{1}^{(1,1)}$ is still an operator satisfying (1) - (6) in Section 2.4. Also, the singular part of $Y_{1}^{(1,1)}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(1)}$ coincides with $Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(1)}$. Thus, from the defining formula, we have

$$
Y_{1}^{(1,1)}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(1)}=Y_{1}^{(1,1),-}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{(1,1),-}\left(a^{(1)},-x\right) a^{(1)}-Y_{1}^{(1,1),-}\left(a^{(1)}, a^{(1)}\right)\right)
$$

We remark that for every $(i, j)>(1,1), Y_{\phi_{(11)}}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ constructed in the base step can bring forth additional singular terms. Indeed, if for some $m \geq 0, a_{m}^{(1)} a^{(2)}$ is a linear combination of $a_{-n_{1}}^{(1)} a_{-n_{2}}^{(1)} \mathbf{1}$, then

$$
Y_{\phi_{1,1}}\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(2)}=-\phi\left(Y\left(a^{(1)}, x\right) a^{(2)}\right)
$$

would include a linear combination of

$$
-\phi\left(a_{-n_{1}}^{(1)} a_{-n_{2}}^{(1)} \mathbf{1}\right) x^{-m-1}
$$

Therefore, to continue with construction, we have to start with $Y_{1}^{(1,1)}$ instead of $Y_{1}$, to incorporate these potential extra singular terms.

Generally, having constructed $Y_{1}^{(i, j)}$ and $Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right)}$ for every $\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right)<(i, j)$ satisfying the conditions, we use Proposition 3.1 to find a homogeneous map $\phi_{i, j+1}: V \rightarrow V$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y_{1}^{(i, j)}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j+1)}-Y_{\phi_{i, j+1}}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j+1)} \\
= & Y_{1}^{(i, j),-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j+1)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{(i, j),-}\left(a^{(j+1)},-x\right) a^{(i)}-Y_{1}^{(i, j),-}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j+1)}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Set $Y_{1}^{(i, j+1)}(u, x) v=Y_{1}^{(i, j)}(u, x) v-Y_{\phi_{i, j+1}}(u, x) v$. Then $Y_{1}^{(i, j+1)}$ is still an operator satisfying (1) - (6) in Section 2.4, and for every $u, v \in V$,

$$
Y_{1}^{(i, j+1)}(u, x) v=Y_{1}(u, x) v-\sum_{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right) \leq(i, j+1)} Y_{\phi_{i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}}}(u, x) v
$$

Also, the singular part of $Y^{(i, j+1)}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j+1)}$ coincides with the singular part of $Y^{(i, j)}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j+1)}$. From the defining formula,

$$
Y^{(i, j+1)}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j+1)}=Y_{1}^{(i, j+1),-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j+1)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{(i, j+1),-}\left(a^{(j+1)},-x\right) a^{(i)}-Y_{1}^{(i, j+1),-}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j+1)}\right)\right)
$$

is determined by its singular part. From skew-symmetry, it is clear that the same identity holds if $a^{(i)}$ and $a^{(j+1)}$ are swapped. Moreover, for every $\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right)<(i, j+1)$,

$$
Y_{1}^{(i, j+1)}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}=Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right)}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}-\sum_{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}+1\right) \leq(k, l) \leq(i, j+1)} Y_{\phi_{k, l}}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right)}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}+\sum_{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}+1\right) \leq(k, l) \leq(i, j+1)} \phi_{k, l}\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}\right) \\
& =Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right)}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\phi_{k, l}$ annihilates all the basis element other than $a_{-m_{1}}^{(k)} a_{-m_{2}}^{(l)} \mathbf{1}$ (in particular, $E_{\mathrm{wt}\left(a^{(k)}\right)+\mathrm{wt}\left(a^{(l)}\right)-1}$ ). Thus,
$Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right)}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, z\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}=Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right),-}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, z\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right),-}\left(a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)},-x\right) a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}-Y_{1}^{\left(i^{\prime}, j^{\prime}\right),-}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}\right)$ leads to
$Y_{1}^{(i, j+1)}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, z\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}=Y_{1}^{(i, j+1),-}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, z\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{(i, j+1),-}\left(a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)},-x\right) a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}-Y_{1}^{(i, j+1),-}\left(a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}, x\right) a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}\right)$.
From skew-symmetry, it is clear that the same identity holds if $a^{\left(i^{\prime}\right)}$ and $a^{\left(j^{\prime}\right)}$ are swapped. Thus the inductive step of the construction is proved. Repeating the process, we find the operator $Y_{1}^{(r, r)}$ satisfying the required conditions.

Theorem 3.4. Let $V$ be a vertex algebra that is freely generated by $S=\left\{a^{(1)}, \ldots, a^{(r)}\right\}$. Then, every cohomology class in in $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ is represented by a map $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$, such that (1) $Y_{1}$ satisfies (1) - (6) in Section 2.4.
(2) For every $1 \leq i, j \leq r$,

$$
Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}=Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(j)},-x\right) a^{(i)}-Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}\right)
$$

(3) For every $p \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(p)}, u, v \in S, Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(u, z_{p+1}\right) v$ converges absolutely to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function.
(4) For every $s, u, v \in S, Y_{1}\left(s, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u, z_{2}\right) v$ convnerges absolutely to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function.

Proof. Let $\Psi$ be a cocycle. Let $\bar{Y}_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$ be the map corresponding to $\Psi$, i.e.,

$$
\bar{Y}_{1}(u, z) v=\Psi(u \otimes v ; z, 0)
$$

Let $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$ be the operator $\bar{Y}_{1}{ }^{(r, r)}$ obtained in Proposition 3.3. Then clearly, $Y_{1}$ satisfies Conditions (1) and (2).

We proceed to check Condition (3). Fix $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r$, then for $u=a^{(i)}, v=a^{(j)}$, since $Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ contains finitely many terms,

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(j)}
$$

is a finite sum of

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right)\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(j)} z_{p+1}^{-m-1}
$$

Recall from [FHL] Section 3.5 (also see [Q1], Theorem 3.4) that the product of any numbers of vertex operators converge to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Thus, the series converges absolutely to a finite sum of $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Similarly, since $Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ contains only finitely many terms,

$$
e^{z_{p+1} D} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}-z_{p+1}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(j)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(j)}
$$

converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. By an argument using $D$-conjugation property and analytic continuation, we see that

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) e^{z_{p+1} D} Y^{-}\left(a^{(j)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(j)}
$$

converges absolutely to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Thus Condition (3) holds for $u=a^{(i)}, v=$ $a^{(j)}$ with $i \leq j$. For the case $u=a^{(j)}, v=a^{(i)}$ with $i<j$, by skew-symmetry,

$$
\begin{gathered}
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y\left(u, z_{p+1}\right) v \\
=Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) e^{z_{p+1} D} Y\left(a^{(i)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(j)}
\end{gathered}
$$

Its convergence follows from the convergence of

$$
e^{z_{p+1} D} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}-z_{p+1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(j)}
$$

and an argument of analytic continuation. Thus Condition (3) holds for $u=a^{(j)}, v=a^{(i)}$ with $i<j$.

To check Condition (4), we evaluate $u_{1}=s, u_{2}=u, v=v$ in the cocycle equation (6) satisfied by $Y_{1}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(s, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u, z_{2}\right) v+Y\left(s, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(u, z_{2}\right) v\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(s, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u, z_{2}\right) v+Y\left(Y_{1}\left(s, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) u, z_{2}\right) v\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, the series

$$
Y_{1}\left(s, z_{1}\right) Y\left(u, z_{2}\right) v+Y\left(s, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(u, z_{2}\right) v
$$

converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. By Condition (3), the second summand $Y\left(s, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(u, z_{2}\right) v$ converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Thus so is the first summand.

Remark 3.5. (1) Theorem 3.4 reduces the computation of $Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ into the computation of its singular part

$$
Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}=\sum_{m \geq 0}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(j)} x^{-m-1}
$$

that consists of finitely many terms. For any fixed $m,\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(j)}$ is in the homogeneous subspace of weight wt $a^{(i)}-m-1+\mathrm{wt} a^{(j)}$. Therefore, the number of free variables appearing $Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ is at most $\sum_{m \geq 1} \operatorname{dim} V_{\left(\mathrm{wt}\left(a^{(i)}\right)-m-1+\mathrm{wt}\left(a^{(j)}\right)\right)}$.
(2) When $u, v$ are generators in $S$, the skew-symmetry is the only condition $Y_{1}(u, x) v$ should satisfy. In case $i>j, Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ should be identical to $e^{x D} Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)},-x\right) a^{(i)}$ and thus is determined. In case $i=j$, the skew-symmetry further reduces the number of free variables.
(3) The proof of Proposition 3.1 fails when there exists relations among the basis elements. For example, when $V$ is the simple affine VOA associated with $\mathfrak{s l}_{2}$ of level 1 , then $e(-1)^{2} \mathbf{1}$ is a singular vector. The construction of $\phi$ in Proposition 3.1 requires that $\phi$ sends $e(-1)^{2} \mathbf{1}$ to the constant term of $Y_{1}(e(-1) \mathbf{1}, x) e(-1) \mathbf{1}$. If the constant term is nonzero, then $\phi$ is

not well-defined. In other words, the regular part may represent a nontrivial cocycle in the cohomology group.

Proposition 3.6. For $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r$, the components of the regular parts of $Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$ and $Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x\right) a^{(i)}$ admit the following formula: for each $n \geq 1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} a^{(j)}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{n+\alpha}}{(n+\alpha)!}(-1)^{\alpha}\binom{n+\alpha-1}{\alpha}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)} \\
& \left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} a^{(i)}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{n+\alpha}}{(n+\alpha)!}(-1)^{\alpha+1}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. We first note that since $Y_{1}$ satisfies skew symmetry, it is necessary that

$$
Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x\right) a^{(i)}=e^{x D} Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)},-x\right) a^{(j)}
$$

the right-hand-side of which is computed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{\alpha} D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!} \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{n}^{d e f} a^{(j)}(-x)^{-n-1}=\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{n}^{d e f} a^{(j)}(-1)^{n+1} x^{-n+\alpha-1} \\
= & \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\left(\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}(-1)^{n+\alpha+1}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{n+\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right) x^{-n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

So for every $n \geq 0$,

$$
\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f} a^{(i)}=\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}(-1)^{n+\alpha+1}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{n+\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}
$$

We now compute regular part of (14), which is contributed only by $\frac{1}{2} e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(j)},-x\right) a^{(i)}$. We compute $\frac{1}{2} e^{x D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(j)},-x\right) a^{(i)}$ as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{\alpha} D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!} \sum_{n \geq 0}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f} a^{(i)}(-x)^{-n-1}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!} \sum_{n+\alpha \geq 0}(-1)^{n+\alpha+1}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n+\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)} x^{-n-1} \\
= & \frac{1}{2} \sum_{n \geq 0}\left(\sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}(-1)^{n+\alpha+1}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n+\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right) x^{-n-1}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{n \geq 1}\left(\sum_{\alpha \geq n} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}(-1)^{\alpha-n+1}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha-n}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right) x^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} a^{(j)}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq n} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}(-1)^{\alpha-n+1}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha-n}^{d e f} a^{(i)}
$$

This essentially implies (16) (simply swap $i$ and $j$ ). To obtain (15), we reorganize the sum over $\alpha \geq n$ to the sum over $\alpha \geq 0$, then use (17),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} a^{(j)} & ==\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{n+\alpha}}{(n+\alpha)!}(-1)^{\alpha+1}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{n+\alpha}}{(n+\alpha)!}(-1)^{\alpha+1} \sum_{\beta \geq 0} \frac{D^{\beta}}{\beta!}(-1)^{\alpha+\beta+1}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha+\beta}^{d e f} a^{(j)} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} D^{n+\alpha}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\alpha} \frac{(-1)^{\beta}}{(n+\alpha-\beta)!\beta!}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the identity

$$
\sum_{\beta=0}^{\alpha} \frac{(-1)^{\beta}}{(n+\alpha-\beta)!\beta!}=\frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{(n+\alpha)!}\binom{\alpha+n-1}{\alpha}
$$

we obtain Formula (15).
3.2. Generating function approach. Instead of determining the $Y_{1}(u, z) v$ for $u, v$ ranging in the basis of $V$ given by (1), we will determine the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)
$$

for each $s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n)} \in S$. We now show that (18) determines $Y_{1}$ uniquely.
Theorem 3.7. For every fixed $1 \leq i_{1} \leq \cdots \leq i_{p} \leq r, 1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{q} \leq r, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{p}, n_{1}, \ldots, n_{q} \in$ $\mathbb{Z}_{+}$with $m_{k} \geq \cdots \geq m_{k+l}$ whenever $i_{k-1}<i_{k}=\cdots=i_{k+l}<i_{k+l+1}$ and $n_{k} \geq \cdots \geq n_{k+l}$ whenever $j_{k-1}<j_{k}=\cdots=j_{k+l}<j_{k+l+1}$, the series

$$
Y_{1}\left(a_{-m_{1}}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{p}}^{(i_{p})} \mathbf{1}, x\right) a_{-n_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-n_{q}}^{(j_{q})} \mathbf{1}
$$

is uniquely determined by (18).
Proof. The conclusion clearly holds when $p=1$. Assume the statement holds for every $a_{-m_{1}}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{p}}^{(i_{p})} \mathbf{1}$ with lower filtration, we use the cocycle condition to form an inductive argument. Recall that the Condition (5) states that for every $v \in V^{\prime}, v_{1}, v_{2}, v_{3} \in V$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v_{2}, z_{2}\right) v_{3}+Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v_{2}, z_{2}\right) v_{3}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) v_{2}, z_{2}\right) v_{3}+Y\left(Y_{1}\left(v_{1}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) v_{2}, z_{2}\right) v_{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Substitute

$$
\begin{aligned}
& z_{2} \mapsto \eta, v_{1} \mapsto a^{\left(i_{1}\right)} \\
& v_{2} \mapsto Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}-\eta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p}\right)}, z_{p}-\eta\right) \mathbf{1} \\
& v_{3} \mapsto Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{q}\right)}, z_{p+q}\right) \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

- The first term of (19) is

$$
\begin{gathered}
E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}-\eta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p}\right)}, z_{p}-\eta\right) \mathbf{1}, \eta\right)\right. \\
\left.\cdot Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{q}\right)}, z_{p+q}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

From an argument with analytic continuation and associativity, it is equal to

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p}\right)}, z_{p}\right) \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{q}\right)}, z_{p+q}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
$$

This is precisely of the same form (18) (with an $e^{z_{p+q} D}$-correction). Thus the first term of (19) is determined by (18).

- The second term of (19) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}-\eta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p}\right)}, z_{p}-\eta\right) \mathbf{1}, \eta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{q}\right)}, z_{p+q}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which contains the action of $Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right)$ on the generating function of

$$
Y_{1}\left(a_{-\dot{m}_{2}}^{(i_{2})} \cdots a_{-\dot{m}_{p}}^{(i_{p})} \mathbf{1}, \eta\right) a_{-\eta_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-\eta_{q}}^{(j_{q})} \mathbf{1}
$$

together with the action of $Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right)$ on the generating function of elements with lower filtration. From the induction hypothesis, this term is also determined by (18).

- The first term of $(20)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}-\eta\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}-\eta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p}\right)}, z_{p}-\eta\right) \mathbf{1}, \eta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{q}\right)}, z_{p+q}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which contains the generating function of

$$
Y_{1}\left(a_{-\dot{m}_{1}}^{(i_{1})} a_{-\dot{m}_{2}}^{(i_{2})} \cdots a_{-\dot{m}_{p}}^{(i_{p})} \mathbf{1}, x\right) a_{-\eta_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-\eta_{q}}^{(j_{q})} \mathbf{1}
$$

that is to be determined. The series also contains generating functions of elements with lower filtration that is already determined by the induction hypothesis.

- The second term of (20) becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}-\eta\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}-\eta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p}\right)}, z_{p}-\eta\right) \mathbf{1}, \eta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{q}\right)}, z_{p+q}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which is determined by

$$
Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}-\eta\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}-\eta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p}\right)}, z_{p}-\eta\right) \mathbf{1}
$$

that is precisely of the same form as (18), thus is determined.
Thus, the generating function of

$$
Y_{1}\left(a_{-\dot{m}_{1}}^{(i_{1})} a_{-\dot{m}_{2}}^{(i_{2})} \cdots a_{-\dot{m}_{p}}^{(i_{p})} \mathbf{1}, x\right) a_{-\eta_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-\eta_{q}}^{(j_{q})} \mathbf{1}
$$

is uniquely determined by (18) via the cocycle equation (19) $=(20)$. So are the individual terms.

Remark 3.8. The generating function approach implicitly requires that (18) is well-defined, i.e., the corresponding series converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. This convergence is automatic when $Y_{1}$ is a cocycle representing a class in $H_{\infty}^{2}(V, V)$. We shall see in the subsequent sections that when $V$ is freely-generated, the convergence also holds automatically. In other words, $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)=H_{\infty}^{2}(V, V)$.

3.3. Multivariable cocycle equation. We determine the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function (18) by induction on wt $s^{(1)}+\mathrm{wt} s^{(2)}+\cdots+\mathrm{wt} s^{(n+1)}$.
3.3.1. The base case. In this case, $n=2$ and wt $s^{(1)}+\mathrm{wt} s^{(2)}+\mathrm{wt} s^{(3)}$ is minimal, where (18) reduces to

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}\right)
$$

Theorem 3.4 Part (3) guarantees that the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function is well-defined. The series inside the parenthesis splits into

$$
Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}+Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}
$$

The minimal requirement implies that $Y^{-}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}$ can only basis elements of the form $s_{-m_{1}} \mathbf{1}$ for some $s \in S$. Then, $Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}$ is determined by $Y_{1}\left(s^{(2)}, x\right) s(s \in S)$ and the $D$ derivative property (9). From Theorem 3.4, it is clear that $Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}$ converges absolutely to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Therefore, so is $Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}$.

With these convergence results, the cocycle equation (6) with $u_{1}=s^{(1)}, u_{2}=s^{(2)}, v=s^{(3)}$ can now be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}\right)+E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}\right)+E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}\right) \\
= & E\left(e^{z_{2} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(3)},-z_{2}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) s^{(2)}\right)+E\left(e^{z_{3} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(3)},-z_{2}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) s^{(2)}\right) \\
& +E\left(e^{z_{2} D} Y\left(s^{(3)},-z_{3}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) s^{(2)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the convergence of the right-hand-side follows from the same argument. The problem of determining (18) reduces to determining

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) s^{(3)}\right)
$$

For each $s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}, s^{(3)} \in S$, we would set (23) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{p_{s^{(1)} s^{(2)} s^{(3)}}^{0}\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{3}}\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{2}}} \mathbf{1}+\sum_{\substack{1 \leq j \leq r \\
m \geq 1}} \frac{p_{s^{(1)} s^{(2)} s^{(3)}}^{i(m)}\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{3}}\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{2}}} a_{-m}^{(i)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\substack{1 \leq j \leq r \\
m_{k} \geq \cdots \geq m_{k+k^{\prime}} \text { if } j_{k-1}<j_{k}=\cdots=j_{k+k^{\prime}}<j_{k+k^{\prime}+1}} \frac{p_{s^{(1)} s^{(2)} s^{(3)}}^{j_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \cdots j_{p}\left(m_{p}\right)}\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{3}}\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{2}}} a_{-m_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots\left(a_{j_{p}}\right)_{-m_{p}} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

These polynomials should satisfy equation (22).

Remark 3.9. We introduced these infinitely many polynomials to understand the cocycle equation (22). By no means shall we attempt to solve them directly.

3.3.2. Checking the convergence. Once we understand (23) (and therefore (21)) for each $s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}, s^{(3)} \in$ $S$ with minimal total weight, we should check that the series

$$
Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(u_{m}, z_{m}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{m+1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{m+2}\right) s^{(3)}
$$

converges in $\left|z_{1}\right|>\cdots>\left|z_{m+2}\right|>0$ to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function for each $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m} \in S$. The convergence is needed to guarantee the existence of certain $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. We shall explain a simple case, that the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(u, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right) s^{(3)}\right)
$$

is well-defined. The argument can be easily generalized to arbitrarily many variables. To see this, recall from [FHL] Section 3.5 (also see [Q1], Theorem 3.4) that the product of any numbers of vertex operators converge to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Therefore, the coefficient of each power of $t$ of the complex series

$$
\left(Y\left(u, z_{1}\right)+t Y_{1}\left(u, z_{1}\right)\right)\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right)+t Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right)\right)\left(Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right)+t Y_{1}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right)\right) s^{(3)}
$$

converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Take out the coefficient of $t$, we see that $E\left(Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right) s^{(3)}+Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right) s^{(3)}+Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right) s^{(3)}\right)$ is well-defined. From Theorem 3.4 Part (3), the rear part $E\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right) s^{(3)}\right)$ is well-defined. From our assumption, the middle part $E\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right) s^{(3)}\right)$ is well-defined. Therefore, the initial part $E\left(Y_{1}\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{3}\right) s^{(3)}\right)$ is well-defined. Since the singular parts reduces the filtration, we conclude that (26) is well-defined as a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function.
3.3.3. The n-variable cocycle equation. Fix $N \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$. Assume that we have computed the $\bar{V}$ valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(t^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(t^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(t^{(m)}, z_{m}\right) t^{(m+1)}\right)
$$

for every $m \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}, t^{(1)}, \ldots, t^{(m+1)} \in S$ with wt $t^{(1)}+\cdots+$ wt $t^{(m+1)}<N$. Assume also that we have shown the convergence of the series

$$
Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}
$$

for every $n \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$ such that wt $s^{(1)}+\cdots+$ wt $s^{(n+1)}=N$. (the base case is proved in the previous section). We analyze its limiting $\bar{V}$-valued rational functions by studying a variant of the cocycle equation (6).

Substitute

$$
z_{2}=z_{n}, u_{1}=s^{(1)}, u_{2}=Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}, v=s^{(n+1)}
$$

in the cocycle equation (6), using our assumption on convergence, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right. \\
& \left.+Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right. \\
& \left.+Y\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The convergence assumption allows us to distribute $E$ to the two summands on the left-hand-side. We may further use associativity, skew-symmetry, and an argument of analytic continuation to disribute $E$ to the two summands on the right-hand-side, and reorganize the iterates on the both sides as products. The cocycle equation is therefore reorganized as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}\right) Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) e^{z_{n} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(n+1)},-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}\right) \\
= & E\left(e^{z_{n} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(n+1)},-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}\right) \\
& +E\left(e^{z_{n} D} Y\left(s^{(n+1)},-z_{n}\right) Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

To analyze the equation, we observe the following:

- (27) may be separated as the sum of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right) \\
& +\sum_{k=2}^{n} E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(k-1)}, z_{k-1}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(k)}, z_{k}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $V$ is freely generated by $S$, from Remark 2.3 , for every $k=2, \ldots, n$, the coefficients of the series

$$
Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(k-1)}, z_{k-1}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(k)}, z_{k}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}
$$

are in $E_{N-1}^{S}$. So the sum of the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function (32) is determined by previous computation.

- Similarly, (29) may be separated as the sum of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(e^{z_{n} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(n+1)},-z_{n}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}\right) \\
& +\sum_{k=2}^{n} E\left(e^{z_{n} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(n+1)},-z_{n}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(k-1)}, z_{k-1}-z_{n}\right) Y^{-}\left(s^{(k)}, z_{k}-z_{n}\right)\right. \\
& \left.\cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly as above, (34) is also determined by previous computation.

In summary, the cocycle equation $(27)+(28)=(29)+(30)$ is now rewritten as $(31)+(32)+$ $(28)=(33)+(34)+(30)$, where $(32),(28),(34)$, and $(30)$ are all determined by previous computation.
3.3.4. The ansatz for the solution the $n$-variable cocycle equation. To study the structure of the solutions of the cocycle equation $(31)+(32)+(28)=(33)+(34)+(30)$, for every choice of $s^{(1)}, s^{(2)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$, we set $(31)$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{(0)}}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}} \mathbf{1}+\sum_{\substack{1 \leq j \leq r \\
m \geq 1}} \frac{p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{j(m)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}} a_{-m}^{(j)}} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\substack{l \geq 2,1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{l} \leq l, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{r} \geq 1, \\
m_{k} \geq \cdots \geq m_{k+k^{\prime}} \text { if } j_{k-1}<j_{k}=\cdots=j_{k+k^{\prime}}<j_{k+k^{\prime}+1}}} \frac{p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{j_{1}\left(m_{1}\right)\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}} a_{-m_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{l}}^{(j_{l})}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{j_{1}\left(m_{1}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)$ are homogeneous polynomial functions, $w_{k}=\mathrm{wt} s^{(k)}$ for $k=$ $1, \ldots, n+1$. Note that (33) is uniquely determined by (31), we see that the equation $(31)+(32)+$ $(28)=(33)+(34)+(30)$ defines a linear nonhomogeneous system of equations concerning the coefficients of the polynomials $p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{j_{1}\left(m_{1}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)$ for $1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{l} \leq l, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{l} \geq 1$.

We determine the degree of $p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{j_{1}\left(m_{1}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)$ explicitly. Note that the total degree of the rational function attached to $a_{-m_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{l}}^{(j_{l})} \mathbf{1}$ is

$$
\operatorname{deg} p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{j_{1}\left(m_{1}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)-n w_{1}-w_{2}-\cdots-w_{n+1}
$$

Now, for any $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}$, the coefficient of $z_{1}^{-\alpha_{1}-1} \cdots z_{n}^{-\alpha_{n}-1}$ in the series defining (31) is of weight

$$
w_{1}-\alpha_{1}-1+\cdots+w_{n}-\alpha_{n}-1+w_{n+1}
$$

So for fixed $1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{l} \leq r$ and $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{l} \geq 1$, the total degree of the rational function attached to $a_{-m_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{l}}^{(j_{l})} \mathbf{1}$ should be $-\alpha_{1}-1-\cdots-\alpha_{n}-1$ satisfying

$$
w_{1}-\alpha_{1}-1+\cdots+w_{n}-\alpha_{n}-1+w_{n+1}=\mathrm{wt} a_{-m_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{l}}^{(j_{l})} \mathbf{1}
$$

Therefore, we see that

$$
\operatorname{deg} p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{j_{1}\left(m_{1}\right)\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}=(n-1) w_{1}+\mathrm{wt} a_{-m_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{l}}^{(j_{l})} \mathbf{1}
$$

In particular, $\operatorname{deg} p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{(0)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=(n-1) w_{1}$.
3.4. Complementary solutions are coboundaries. It is know from elementary linear algebra that the general solution of a nonhomogeneous linear system of equations is the sum of a particular solution and the complementary solution, namely, the general solution of the corresponding homogeneous linear system. In our case, the homogeneous system is given by $(31)=(33)$. A solution of the homogeneous system can be viewed a cocycle $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$, such that
(1) (31) makes sense for every $n \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$ with $\mathrm{wt} s^{(1)}+\cdots+\mathrm{wt} s^{(n+1)}=N$.

(2) For every $m \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}, t^{(1)}, \ldots, t^{(m+1)} \in S$ with $\mathrm{wt} t^{(1)}+\cdots+\mathrm{wt} t^{(m+1)}<N$,

$$
Y_{1}\left(t^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(t^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(t^{(m)}, z_{m}\right) t^{(m+1)}=0
$$

In this section we shall focus on the homogeneous system and prove the following theorem:
Theorem 3.10. Let $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$ be a linear map such that
(1) $Y_{1}$ satisfies $(1)-(6)$ in Section 2.4 .
(2) For every $s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$, such that $\mathrm{wt} s^{(1)}+\cdots+\mathrm{wt} s^{(n+1)}=N$,

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)
$$

is a well-defined $\bar{V}$-valued rational function.
(3) For every $t^{(1)}, \ldots, t^{(m)}, t^{(m+1)} \in S$ with $\mathrm{wt} t^{(1)}+\cdots+\mathrm{wt} t^{(m+1)}<N$,

$$
Y_{1}\left(t^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(t^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(t^{(m)}, z_{m}\right) t^{(m+1)}=0
$$

Then there exists a coboundary $\delta \Phi$ such that for every $s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$, $E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)=(\delta \Phi)\left(s^{(1)} \otimes Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)} ; z_{1}, 0\right)$. In other words, the complementary solutions of the nonhomogeneous system of linear equations $(31)+(32)+(28)=(33)+(34)+(30)$ are all coboundaries.

We shall prove this theorem by proving the following series of intermediate results.
Proposition 3.11. Let $Y_{1}$ be as in Theorem 3.10. Then for every $s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$, (31) is a $\bar{V}$-valued polynomial function in $z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}$, i.e, there exists no poles.

Proof. Let $w_{i}=\mathrm{wt} s^{(k)}, k=1, \ldots, n$. We substitute (31) by (35). Then $(31)=(33)$ is rewritten as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{p_{s^{(1)}, \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{2}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}} \mathbf{1}+\frac{p_{s^{(1)}, \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{i(m)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}} a_{-m}^{(i)}} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\substack{l \geq 2,1 \leq i_{l} \leq \cdots \leq i_{l} \leq l, \\
m_{1}, \ldots, m_{r} \geq 1, \\
m_{j} \geq \cdots \geq m_{j+k}}} \frac{p_{s^{(1)}, \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}} a_{-m_{1}}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{l}}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1} \\
& \text { if } i_{j-1}<i_{j}=\cdots=i_{j+k}<i_{j+k+1} \\
& =\frac{p_{s^{(n+1)} s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n)}}^{2}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right)}{\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}}} \mathbf{1}+\frac{p_{s^{(n+1)} s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n)}}^{i(m)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right)}{\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}}} e^{z_{n} D} a_{-m}^{(i)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\substack{l \geq 2,1 \leq i_{l} \leq \cdots \leq i_{l} \leq l, \\
m_{1}, \ldots, m_{r} \geq 1, \\
m_{j} \geq \cdots \geq m_{j+k}}} \frac{p_{s^{(n+1)} s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right)}{\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}}} e^{z_{n} D} a_{-m_{1}}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-m_{l}}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

We prove the conclusion in the following steps:

- We first show that $p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=0$. From the coefficient of $\mathbf{1}$ of the equation, we see that

$$
\frac{p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}}=\frac{p_{s^{(n+1) s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n)}}}^{(0)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right)}{\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}}}
$$

Multiplying both sides out, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}} \\
= & p_{s^{(n+1) s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n)}}}^{(0)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, it is necessary that

$$
\prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}} \text { divides } p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)
$$

However, from (36), $\operatorname{deg} p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}}^{(0)}=n(n-1) w_{1}$ that is strictly smaller than $\operatorname{deg} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-\right.$ $\left.z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}=(n-1) w_{1}+w_{2}+\cdots+w_{k}$. So the only possibility is that $p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=0$.

- We then show that

$$
p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=0
$$

whenever

$$
\text { wt } a_{-\left(m_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-\left(m_{l}\right.}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1}<w_{2}+\cdots+w_{n}
$$

Indeed, since the coefficients of elements of lower weights are all zero, $e^{z_{n}} D$ contributes only its constant term, namely the identity. Then the same arguments applies.

- Now we show that

$$
p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=0
$$

whenever

$$
\text { wt } a_{-\left(m_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-\left(m_{l}\right.}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1}<w_{1}+w_{2}+\cdots+w_{n}+w_{n+1}
$$

Again, $e^{z_{n} D}$ on the right-hand-side does not have any contributions to the coefficient of wt $a_{-\left(m_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-\left(m_{l}\right.}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1}$. So from the coefficient, we similarly see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}} \\
= & p_{s^{(n+1) s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n)}}}^{(0) \ldots s^{(n)}} \ldots z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, it is necessary that

$$
\prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}} \text { divides } p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(0) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)
$$

To find out other restrictions, we rotate the choices of $s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)}$ and consider the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(3)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(1)}\right)
$$

By the same procedure (though with slightly different inputs), we obtain the

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{s^{(2)} \ldots s^{(n+1)} s^{(1)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k+2}} \\
= & p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(1)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) z_{1}^{w_{2}+w_{1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{2}+w_{k+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \operatorname{divides} p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right)
$$

Perform the change of variables $-z_{n} \mapsto z_{1}, z_{1}-z_{n} \mapsto z_{2}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n} \mapsto z_{n}$, we see that

$$
z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \operatorname{divides} p_{s^{(1)}\left(\ldots s^{(n+1)}\right.}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)
$$

Combining (39) and (42), we see that

$$
z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}} \operatorname{divides} p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)
$$

However, from (36),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{deg} p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)} & =(n-1) w_{1}+\mathrm{wt} a_{-\cdot m_{1}}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-\cdot m_{l}}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1} \\
& <n w_{1}+w_{2}+\cdots+w_{l}=\operatorname{deg} z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

So again, the only possibility is that $p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(1)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)=0$.

- Now we consider $p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{(1)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)$ with

$$
\text { wt } a_{-\cdot m_{1}}^{(i_{1})} \cdots a_{-\cdot m_{l}}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1}=w_{1}+w_{2}+\cdots+w_{n}+w_{n+1}
$$

From an identical argument, we see that (43) still holds. So the coefficient

$$
\frac{p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)}{z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}}
$$

of $s^{(2)}\left(\right.$. - $m_{1} \cdots a_{-\cdot m_{l}}^{(i_{l})} \mathbf{1}$ is a polynomial function.

- For the coefficient of elements with higher weight, it suffices to take care of the contribution by $e^{z_{n} D}$. However, since the coefficients of lower weights elements are all polynomials, the identity (37) is now modified as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{i_{1}\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}} \\
