= & p_{s^{(n+1)} s^{(1)} \ldots s^{(n)}}^{(1)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
+\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{n}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{n+1}+w_{k+1}} \cdot z_{1}^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k}} \cdot(\text { some polynomial })
$$

the identity (40) is now modified as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{s^{(3) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}{ }_{s^{(1)}}^{\left(m_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{n}\right)\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k+2}} \\
= & p_{s^{(1) \ldots s^{(n+1)}}^{\left(i_{1}\right) \ldots i_{l}\left(m_{l}\right)}\left(-z_{n}, z_{1}-z_{n}, \ldots, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) z_{1}^{w_{2}+w_{1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{2}+w_{k+1}} \\
& +\left(-z_{n}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{n+1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(-z_{k}\right)^{w_{1}+w_{k+2}} \cdot z_{1}^{w_{2}+w_{1}} \prod_{k=2}^{n}\left(z_{1}-z_{k}\right)^{w_{2}+w_{k+1}} \cdot(\text { some polynomial })
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the divisible relation (43) still holds.
So we showed that the coefficients of all elements in the (35) are polynomial functions. Thus, (31) is a $\bar{V}$-valued polynomial function.

Proposition 3.12. Let $Y_{1}$ be as in Theorem 3.10. Then for every $r \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}, v^{\prime} \in V, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n)}, s^{(n+1)} \in$ $S$ and every permutation $\sigma$ of $\{1, \ldots, n+1\}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(\sigma(1))}, z_{\sigma(1)}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(\sigma(2))}, z_{\sigma(2)}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(\sigma(r))}, z_{\sigma(r)}\right) Y\left(s^{(\sigma(n+1))}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. From the creation property and an argument of analytic continuation, we know that the series

$$
Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}
$$

converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. Moreover, From the commutativity of the vertex operators, using an argument of analytic continuation, we see that for every permutation $\sigma$ on $\{2, \ldots, n, n+1\}$

$$
\begin{gathered}
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right) \\
=E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(\sigma(2))}, z_{\sigma(2)}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(\sigma(r))}, z_{\sigma(r)}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Using the assumption that $Y_{1}\left(s^{(i)}, z\right)$ annihilates any element in $E_{N-1}^{S}$, we may replace all the $Y$ 's by $Y^{+}$, to obtain the conclusion for any permutaiton $\sigma$ of $\{2, \ldots, n, n+1\}$.

It remains to show the equality for $\sigma=(12)$. Again from the commutativity of vertex operator, using an argument of analytic continuation, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(e^{z_{n} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(n+1)},-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}\right) \\
= & E\left(e^{z_{n} D} Y_{1}\left(s^{(n+1)},-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{n}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n-1)}, z_{n-1}-z_{n}\right) s^{(n)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Again we may replace $Y$ by $Y^{+}$. The conclusion then follows from the equation $(31)=(33)$.

Proof of Theorem 3.10. Construct a 1-cochain by defining a linear homogeneous map $\phi: V \rightarrow V$, such that
$\phi\left(s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right)=-\operatorname{Res}_{z_{1}=0} z_{1}^{-m_{1}} \cdots \operatorname{Res}_{z_{n+1}=0} z_{n+1}^{-m_{n+1}} E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)$ for every $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n+1} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(n+1)} \in S$, and

$$
\phi(v)=0
$$

for any other basis element $v$. In particular, we note that $\phi$ annihilates $E_{N}^{S}$ for every $N<$ wt $s^{(1)}+\cdots+$ wt $s^{(n+1)}$.

We check that $\phi$ is well-defined. From Formula (3.1.9) in [LL], for every permutation $\sigma \in$ $\operatorname{Sym}\{1, \ldots, n+1\}$, the difference of $s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}$ and $s_{-m_{\sigma(1)}}^{(n+1)} \cdots s_{-m_{\sigma(n+1)}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}$ differs by an element in $E_{N}^{S}$ for $N \leq$ wt $s^{(1)}+\cdots+$ wt $s^{(n+1)}-1$ that is annihilated by $\phi$. Therefore, $\phi$ is well-defined if and only if

$$
\phi\left(s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right)=\phi\left(s_{-m_{\sigma(1)}}^{(n+1)} \cdots s_{-m_{\sigma(n+1)}}^{(\sigma(n+1) \mathbf{1}} \mathbf{1}\right)
$$

But this is guaranteed by Proposition 3.12.
We check that $\phi$ commutes with $D$. From the $D$-derivative property (10) of $Y_{1}$ and that of $Y$, we have
$D E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)=\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{1}}+\cdots+\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{n+1}}\right) E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)$
Taking $\operatorname{Res}_{z_{1}=0} z_{1}^{-m_{1}} \cdots \operatorname{Res}_{z_{n+1}=0} z_{n+1}^{-m_{n+1}}$ on both sides, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& D \phi\left(s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & \sum_{i=1}^{n+1} m_{i} \phi\left(s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{i}-1}^{(i)} \cdots s_{-m_{n+1}-1}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & \phi\left(D s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $\phi$ commutes with $D$. Now we consider the coboundary defined by $\phi$. We study the coboundary $\delta \Phi$ corresponding to $\phi$ using (11). Since $\phi$ annihilates $E_{N}^{S}$ for every $N<$ wt $s^{(1)}+$ $\cdots+$ wt $s^{(n+1)}, Y_{1}\left(\phi\left(s^{(1)}\right), x\right) s_{m_{2}}^{(2)} \cdots s_{m_{n}}^{(n)} s^{(n+1)}$ and $Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, x\right) \phi\left(s_{m_{2}}^{(2)} \cdots s_{m_{n}}^{(n)} s^{(n+1)}\right)$ are both zero for every $m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}$. So,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (\delta \Phi)\left(s^{(1)} \otimes Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}-z_{n+1}\right) s^{(n+1)} ; z_{1}, z_{n+1}\right) \\
= & E\left(-\phi\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}-z_{n+1}\right) s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)\right) \\
= & E\left(-\phi\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) Y\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)\right) \\
= & -E\left(\sum_{m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n+1} \in \mathbb{Z}} \phi\left(s_{m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right) z_{1}^{-m_{1}-1} \cdots z_{n+1}^{-m_{n+1}-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $V$ is freely generated by $S$, and $\phi\left(s_{m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right) \neq 0$ only when $m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n+1}<0$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (\delta \Phi)\left(s^{(1)} \otimes Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}-z_{n+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}-z_{n+1}\right) s^{(n+1)} ; z_{1}, z_{n+1}\right) \\
= & -E\left(\sum_{m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n+1} \geq 1} \phi\left(s_{-m_{1}}^{(1)} \cdots s_{-m_{n+1}}^{(n+1)} \mathbf{1}\right) z_{1}^{m_{1}-1} \cdots z_{n+1}^{m_{n+1}-1}\right) \\
& =E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(s^{(n+1)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The conclusion then follows by evaluating $z_{n+1}=0$.
Remark 3.13. (1) Theorem 3.10 basically states that the complementary solutions of the cocycle equation are all coboundaries. Therefore, to solve the cocycle equation, it suffices to find one particular solution. We shall achieve this in the next section.
(2) The proof of Theorem 3.10 fails when there exists relations among the basis vectors. For example, in the simple affine VOA associated with $s l_{2}$ with level $n$, we have $e(-1)^{n+1} \mathbf{1}=0$. In this case, $\phi$ is not well-defined if the constant term

$$
Y_{1}\left(e(-1) \mathbf{1}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(e(-1) \mathbf{1}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(e(-1) \mathbf{1}, z_{n}\right) e(-1) \mathbf{1}
$$

is nonzero. So in this case, the complementary solution might not be a coboundary and thus might represent a nontrivial cohomology class.

# 4. Particular SOLUTION: THE BASE CASE 

In this section, we give a recursive construction $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$ based on the one-variable cocycle on the generators discussed in Section 3.1. We prove that $Y_{1}$ is a particular solution and satisfy the properties when the generators are of minimal weight. The inductive step is left for the next section.
4.1. Modes for the $Y_{1}$-operator. Recall that $S=\left\{a^{(1)}, \ldots, a^{(r)}\right\}$. Assume that for every $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r$, we have

$$
Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}=B\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) \mathbf{1} x^{-\mathrm{wt}\left(a^{(i)}\right)-\mathrm{wt}\left(a^{(j)}\right)}+\sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}} M_{m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) x^{-m-1}
$$

where for each $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r, n \in \mathbb{N}$,

$$
B\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) \in \mathbb{C}, M_{m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) \in V
$$

Define

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{1}: S & \rightarrow(\operatorname{End} V)\left[\left[x, x^{-1}\right]\right] \\
a^{(i)} & \mapsto Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right)=\sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} x^{-n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

For each $i=1, \ldots ., r$, we define the $\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}$ by specifying its image on the basis elements of $V$.
(1) $\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} \mathbf{1}=0$ for every $m \in \mathbb{Z}$.

(2) If $i \leq j$, then

$$
\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(j)}= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } m \geq \operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(i)}\right)+\operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(j)}\right) \\ B\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) \mathbf{1} & \text { if } m=\operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(i)}\right)+\operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(j)}\right)-1 \\ M_{m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) & \text { if } m<\operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(i)}\right)+\operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(j)}\right)-1\end{cases}
$$

From Proposition 3.6, for $m \geq 1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
M_{-m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) & =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{m+\alpha}}{(m+\alpha)!}(-1)^{\alpha}\binom{m+\alpha-1}{\alpha} M_{\alpha}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{m+\alpha}}{(m+\alpha)!}\binom{-m}{\alpha} M_{\alpha}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

(3) If $i>j$, then

$$
\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(j)}=\operatorname{Res}_{x} x^{m} e^{x D} Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)},-x\right) a^{(i)}
$$

This allows us to extend our maps $B$ and $M_{m}$ respectively to $B: S \times S \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ and $M_{m}$ : $S \times S \rightarrow V$, satisfying the relations

$$
\begin{gathered}
B\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right)=(-1)^{\operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(i)}\right)+\operatorname{wt}\left(a^{(j)}\right)} B\left(a^{(j)}, a^{(i)}\right) \\
M_{m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right)=\sum_{\alpha \geq 0}(-1)^{m+\alpha+1} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!} M_{m+\alpha}\left(a^{(j)}, a^{(i)}\right), m \geq 0 \\
M_{-m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}(-1)^{\alpha+1} \frac{D^{m+\alpha}}{(m+\alpha)!} M_{\alpha}\left(a^{(j)}, a^{(i)}\right), m \geq 1
\end{gathered}
$$

Assuming that for every $i$, $\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} v$ is defined for every $v \in E_{N}^{S}$ for every $N<\mathrm{wt} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+\cdots+$ wt $a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}$, we recursively define $\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}$ as follows:
(4) If $m<0,1 \leq i \leq r$, and $1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{p} \leq r$, we set

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{-n_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-n_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
= & \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k=1}^{p} a_{-n_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-n_{k-1}}^{(j_{k-1})} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j_{k})}\right)_{m-n_{k}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j_{k})}\right)_{m-n_{k}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-n_{k-1}}^{(j_{k-1})} \cdots a_{-n_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j_{k})}\right)_{m-n_{k}-\alpha}^{d e f}$ is defined via the procedure described in Section 3.2, Theorem 3.7. Since $a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)} \in E_{\text {wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(j)}-1}$, following the procedure described in Theorem 3.7, the definition will eventually reduce to $\left(a^{(i)}\right)^{d e f}$ on elements with lower filtrations. Note that this formula is consistent with the case when $p=1$.
(5) If $m \geq 0$ and $1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{p} \leq r$, we define

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{-n_{1}}^{(j_{1})} \cdots a_{-n_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
= & a_{-n_{1}}^{(j_{1})}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{-n_{2}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-n_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-n_{1}}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-n_{2}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-n_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}-a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-n_{1}}^{d e f}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-n_{2}} \cdots a_{-n_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j_{1})}\right)_{m-n_{1}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{m-n_{1}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-n_{2}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-n_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma 4.1. For every $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}, 1 \leq i, j \leq r$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) \\
= & -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as element in EndV.

Proof. From the skew-symmetry,

$$
\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}=\sum_{\beta \geq \alpha}(-1)^{\beta+1} \frac{D^{\beta-\alpha}}{(\beta-\alpha)!}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}
$$

So

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta \geq \alpha} \frac{(-1)^{\beta+1}}{(\beta-\alpha)!}\left(D^{\beta-\alpha}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta \geq \alpha} \frac{(-1)^{\beta+1} \cdot(-1)^{\beta-\alpha}}{(\beta-\alpha)!}(m+n-\alpha) \cdots(m+n-\beta+1)\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\beta} \\
= & \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{\beta+1} \sum_{0 \leq \alpha \leq \beta}\binom{m}{\alpha}\binom{-m-n+\beta-1}{\beta-\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\beta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that

$$
(-1)^{\beta+1} \sum_{0 \leq \alpha \leq \beta}\binom{m}{\alpha}\binom{-m-n+\beta-1}{\beta-\alpha}=-{n \over \beta}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}=-\sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\beta}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\beta}
$$

So the first half of the identity is proved. A similar argument proves the second half.
Proposition 4.2. For every $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}, 1 \leq i, j \leq r$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{(j)}\right] \mathbf{1}+\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, \left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right] \mathbf{1} } \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} \mathbf{1}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f} \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. For $m, n \in \mathbb{N}$, the formula automatically holds. For $m \in \mathbb{N}, n \in \mathbb{Z}_{-}$and $m \in \mathbb{Z}_{-}, n \in \mathbb{N}$, the formula follows directly from the definition. We check the case when $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}_{-}$in detail. For convenience, we substitute $m \mapsto-m, n \mapsto-n$ and set $m, n \geq 1$. By definition,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} a_{-n}^{(j)} \mathbf{1}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha} \mathbf{1} \\
& a_{-n}^{(j)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} \mathbf{1}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{-m}^{(i)}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} \mathbf{1}=0 \\
& \left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} a_{-m}^{(i)} \mathbf{1}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{-n}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha} \mathbf{1}=-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{-m}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality follows from Lemma 4.1. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f}, a_{-n}^{(j)}\right] \mathbf{1}+\left[a_{-m}^{(i)}, \left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f}\right] \mathbf{1}} \\
= & \frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha} \mathbf{1}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha} \mathbf{1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

The conclusion then follows from $v_{n}^{d e f} \mathbf{1}=0$ for each $v=a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}$ and $n \in \mathbb{Z}$.
4.2. Commutator condition. Throughout this section, we assume that for each $m, n \in \mathbb{N}$, $1 \leq i, j, k \leq r$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{(j)}\right] a^{(k)}+\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, \left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right] a^{(k)}} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} ^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We refer this formula as the commutator condition.
The following lemma plays a key role in the cocycle construction.

Lemma 4.3. Fix $w \in V, i, j, k \in\{1, \ldots, r\}$. If the commutator formula

$$
\left[u_{m}^{d e f}, v_{n}\right] w+\left[u_{m}, v_{n}^{d e f}\right] w=\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(u_{\alpha}^{d e f} v\right)_{m+n-\alpha} w+\left(u_{\alpha} v\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f} w\right)
$$

holds for $(u, v)=\left(a^{(i)}, a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right),\left(a^{(j)}, a_{\alpha}^{(k)} a^{(i)}\right)$, and $\left(a^{(k)}, a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)$ and for arbitrary $m, n, p \in$ $\mathbb{Z}, \alpha \in \mathbb{N}$, then the commutator condition implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left[a_{n}^{(j)}, a_{p}^{(k)}\right]\right] w+\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{n+p-\alpha}+\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha} a^{(k)}\right)_{n+p-\alpha}^{d e f}\right] w} \\
& +\left[\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\left[a_{p}^{(k)}, a_{m}^{(i)}\right]\right] w+\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{p}{\alpha}\left[a_{n}^{(j)},\left(\left(a^{(k)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+p-\alpha}+\left(\left(a^{(k)}\right)_{\alpha} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+p-\alpha}^{d e f}\right] w \\
& +\left[\left(a^{(k)}\right)_{p}^{d e f}\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{n}^{(j)}\right]\right] w+\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left[a_{p}^{(k)},\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right] w
\end{aligned}
$$

is zero.
Proof. We start from (45). Using the commutator formula for $\left[a_{n}^{(j)}, a_{p}^{(k)}\right]$, we may rewrite (45) as $\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\left(\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{n+p-\alpha}\right]+\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{n+p-\alpha}^{d e f}\right]+\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{n+p-\alpha}\right]\right) w$.

We apply the assumption on the first two brackets, and apply the commutator formula for the third bracket, so (45) equals

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}+\left(a_{\beta}^{(i)} a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f}\right) w \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(a_{\beta}^{(i)}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w
\end{aligned}
$$

We now handle (46). Likewise, using the commutator formula for $\left[a_{p}^{(k)}, a_{m}^{(i)}\right]$, we may rewrite (46) as
$\sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{p}{\beta}\left(\left[\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f},\left(a_{\beta}^{(k)} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+p-\beta}\right]+\left[a_{n}^{(j)},\left(a_{\beta}^{(k)} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+p-\beta}^{d e f}\right]+\left[a_{n}^{(j)},\left(\left(a^{(k)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right)_{m+p-\beta}\right]\right) w$.
Using Lemma 4.1, we may rewrite (46) as
$-\sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(\left[\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f},\left(a_{\beta}^{(i)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+p-\beta}\right]+\left[a_{n}^{(j)},\left(a_{\beta}^{(i)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+p-\beta}^{d e f}\right]+\left[a_{n}^{(j)},\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+p-\beta}\right]\right) w$.
We apply the assumption on the first two brackets, and apply the commutator formula for the third bracket, then swap the order of summation, to rewrite (46) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a_{\beta}^{(i)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a_{\beta}^{(i)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) w \\
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\beta}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\alpha} w
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we handle (47). Likewise, using the commutator formula for $\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{n}^{(j)}\right]$, we may rewrite (47) as
$\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left[\left(a^{(k)}\right)_{p}^{d e f},\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}\right]+\left[a_{p}^{(k)},\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}\right]+\left[a_{p}^{(k)},\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right] w\right.$
We apply the assumption on the first two brackets, and apply the commutator formula for the third bracket, then swap the order of summation, to rewrite (47) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{p}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(k)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}+\left(a_{\beta}^{(k)} a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f}\right) w \\
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{p}{\beta}\left(a_{\beta}^{(k)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w
\end{aligned}
$$

Apply Lemma 4.1 to swap $a^{(k)}$ and $a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}$ in the first line, swap $a^{(k)}$ and $\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}$ in the second line, we conclude that (47) is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m+n-\alpha}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}+\left(\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f}\right) w \\
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m+n-\alpha}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $(45)+(46)+(47)$ is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}+\left(a_{\beta}^{(i)} a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f}\right) w \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(a_{\beta}^{(i)}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w \\
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a_{\beta}^{(i)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a_{\beta}^{(i)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) w \\
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\beta}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\alpha} w \\
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m+n-\alpha}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}+\left(\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f}\right) w \\
& -\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m+n-\alpha}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w
\end{aligned}
$$

Equivalently, $(45)+(46)+(47)=0$ means

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(\left(\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f}, a_{\alpha}^{(j)}\right] a^{(k)}+\left[a_{\beta}^{(i)},\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f}\right] a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}\right) w \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta}\left(\left(\left[a_{\beta}^{(i)}, a_{\alpha}^{(j)}\right] a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f}\right) w \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m+n-\alpha}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f}+v\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m+n-\alpha}{\beta}\left(\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f} w
\end{aligned}
$$

Now for (48), we apply the commutator condition to rewrite it as

$$
\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\binom{m}{\beta} \sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty}\binom{\beta}{\gamma}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\gamma}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta+\alpha-\gamma} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta+\alpha-\gamma}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w
$$

Note that $\gamma \leq \beta$, and we have

$$
\binom{\beta}{\gamma}\binom{m}{\beta}=\binom{m}{\gamma}\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\gamma}
$$

so we may rewrite (48) as

$$
\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\binom{m}{\gamma}\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\gamma}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\gamma}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta+\alpha-\gamma} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta+\alpha-\gamma}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta} w
$$

Substitute $\beta \mapsto \beta-\alpha+\gamma$ and rearrange the order of summation, we rewrite (48) as

$$
\sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\binom{m}{\gamma}\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\gamma}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\gamma} w
$$

Note that $\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\alpha} \neq 0$ only when $\alpha \leq \beta$. So (48) is equal to

$$
\sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\gamma}\left(\sum_{0 \leq \alpha \leq \beta}\binom{n}{\alpha}\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\alpha}\right)\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\gamma}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\gamma} w
$$

Note that

$$
\sum_{0 \leq \alpha \leq \beta}\binom{n}{\alpha}\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\alpha}=\binom{m+n-\gamma}{\beta}
$$

So, (48) is

$$
\sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\gamma}\binom{m+n-\gamma}{\beta}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\gamma}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\gamma} w
$$

which is precisely (50).
For (49), we apply the commutator formula of the vertex operator, and follow a similar procedure as above, to reorganize it as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\beta} \sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty}\binom{\beta}{\gamma}\left(\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha+\beta-\gamma} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f} w \\
= & \sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\binom{m}{\gamma}\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\gamma}\left(\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha+\beta-\gamma} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\alpha-\beta}^{d e f} w \\
= & \sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\gamma} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty} \sum_{0 \leq \alpha \leq \beta}\binom{n}{\alpha}\binom{m-\gamma}{\beta-\alpha}\left(\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\gamma}^{d e f} w \\
= & \sum_{\gamma=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\gamma} \sum_{\beta=0}^{\infty}\binom{m+n-\gamma}{\beta}\left(\left(a_{\gamma}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{\beta} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n+p-\beta-\gamma}^{d e f} w
\end{aligned}
$$

which is precisely (51). Therefore, we proved that $(48)+(49)=(50)+(51)$.

# 4.3. Commutator formula: minimal weight case. 

Proposition 4.4. Let $a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}, a^{(k)} \in S$ such that they are of minimal weight. Then the commutator formula (44) holds for every $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Proof. When $m \in \mathbb{N}, n \in \mathbb{Z}_{-}$or $m \in \mathbb{Z}_{-}, n \in \mathbb{N}$, (44) trivially follows from the definition. We check (44) for $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}_{-}$. For convenience, we substitute $m \mapsto-m$ and $n \mapsto-n$ in (44) and set $m, n \geq 1$. So we are aiming to prove

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f}, a_{-n}^{(j)}\right] a^{(k)}+\left[a_{-m}^{(i)},\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f}\right] a^{(k)}} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{-m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By definition,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f}, a_{-n}^{(j)}\right] a_{-1}^{(k)}} \mathbf{1}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{-m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} \\
& {\left[a_{-m}^{(i)},\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f}\right] a_{-1}^{(k)}} \mathbf{1}=-\left[\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f}, a_{-m}^{(i)}\right] a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{-n}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(i)}\right)_{-n-m-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(i)}\right)_{-n-m-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{-m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality follows from Lemma 4.1. Adding up these two equalities, we obtain (52).

Remark 4.5. It should be remarked that the minimal weight assumption is not needed if the operator product expansion of the vertex operator is linear, so that $a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}, a_{\alpha}^{(k)} a^{(i)}$ and $a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}$ are linear combinations of $\mathbf{1}$ and $a_{-q}^{(p)} \mathbf{1}$. In general, $a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}, a_{\alpha}^{(k)} a^{(i)}$ and $a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}$ might be linear combinations of $a_{-\left.q_{1}\right]}^{(p_{1})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{s}\right]}^{(p_{s})} \mathbf{1}$. We will handle the situation with induction and analytic continuation. The minimal weight case serves as the starting point of the induction.

Proposition 4.6. For $i, j, k=1, \ldots, r$ such that $a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}$ and $a^{(k)}$ are of minimal weight,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x_{1}\right), Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{2}\right)\right] a^{(k)}+\left[Y\left(a^{(i)}, x_{1}\right), Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{2}\right)\right] a^{(k)}} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(Y\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}, x_{2}\right) a^{(k)}+Y_{1}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}, x_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}\right)^{\alpha} x_{1}^{-1} \delta\left(\frac{x_{2}}{x_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. With the minimal weight assumption, we already showed that (44) holds for all integers. We now multiply (44) by $x_{1}^{-m-1} x_{2}^{-n-1}$ and sum over all $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, to see that the left-hand-side of $(53)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{m, n \in \mathbb{Z}} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) x_{1}^{-m-1} x_{2}^{-n-1} \\
= & \sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} ^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\binom{m-n+\alpha}{\alpha} x_{1}^{-m+n-\alpha-1} x_{2}^{-n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}\binom{m-n+\alpha}{\alpha} x_{1}^{-m+n-\alpha-1} x_{2}^{-n-1}=\sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}}(-1)^{\alpha}\binom{-m+n-1}{\alpha} x_{1}^{-m+n-\alpha-1} x_{2}^{-n-1} \\
= & \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}\right)^{\alpha} x_{1}^{-m+n-1} x_{2}^{-n-1}=x_{2}^{-m-1} \sum_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}\right)^{\alpha} x_{1}^{-m+n-1} x_{2}^{m-n} \\
= & x_{2}^{-m-1} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}\right)^{\alpha} x_{1}^{-1} \delta\left(\frac{x_{2}}{x_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the left-hand-side of (53) is expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) x_{2}^{-m-1} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}\right)^{\alpha} x_{1}^{-1} \delta\left(\frac{x_{2}}{x_{1}}\right) \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(Y\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}, x_{2}\right) a^{(k)}+Y_{1}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}, x_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}\right)^{\alpha} x_{1}^{-1} \delta\left(\frac{x_{2}}{x_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which is precisely the right-hand-side of (53).

Corollary 4.7. For $i, j, k=1, \ldots, r$ such that $a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}$ and $a^{(k)}$ are of minimal weight, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)}, z_{3}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)}, z_{3}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)}, z_{3}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)}, z_{3}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)}, z_{3}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)+E\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)}, z_{3}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, the cocycle equation with $u=a^{(i)}, v=a^{(j)}, w=a^{(k)}$ is satisfied.
Proof. From the Proposition 4.6, and the fact that $\delta$-function is an expansion of zero, we conclude that

$$
\begin{gathered}
E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right) \\
=E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

The first equality then follows from the creation property, the $D$-conjugation formula and a change of variables. The second equality follows from the followign trivial variant of (54), namely,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(e^{z_{2} D} Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)},-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}\right)+E\left(e^{z_{2} D} Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(k)},-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}\right) \\
= & E\left(e^{z_{2} D} Y_{1}\left(a^{(k)},-z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}\right)+E\left(e^{z_{2} D} Y\left(a^{(k)},-z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In greater detail, if we pass $e^{z_{2} D}$ in the left-hand-side through the first operator, then apply skew-symmetry to the second operator, we recover the left-hand-side of (54). We then apply the skew-symmmetry to the first operator on the right-hand-side. This process yields the equality

$$
\begin{gathered}
E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right) \\
=E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)+E\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

So the cocycle equation (6) with $u_{1}=a^{(i)}, u_{2}=a^{(j)}$ and $v=a^{(k)}$ holds. Then we use creation property, $D$-conjugation formula and a change of variables to recover the second identity.
4.4. Checking the convergence: minimal weight case. To prepare for the next level of calculation, we need the following proposition.

Proposition 4.8. Let $a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}, a^{(k)} \in S$ such that they are of minimal weight. Then for every $p \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(p)} \in S$, the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)
$$

is well-defined.

Proof. We first work out the case $j \leq k$. We already know the convergence of

$$
E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(u, z_{p+1}\right) v\right)
$$

for every $u, v \in S$ from Theorem 3.4 (3). With the minimal weight assumption, it is clear that the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)
$$

is well-defined. It suffices to study the series

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)} \\
= & Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)} \\
& +Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)}
\end{aligned}
$$

- We first study (57). By definition,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a_{-n}^{(j)} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+2}^{n-1}=\sum_{m \geq 0}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{-n}^{(j)} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{-m-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
= & \sum_{m \geq 0}\left(a_{-n}^{(j)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1}+\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1}-a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1}\right) z_{p+1}^{-m-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
& +\sum_{m \geq 0} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m-n-\alpha} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m-n-\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) z_{p+1}^{-m-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that for each fixed $n \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$, the first two summands in (59) contains only finitely elements. If we sum up (59) with $n \geq 1$ and act $Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right)$, what we get is simply

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)} \\
& +Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)} \\
& -Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The series differs from the series

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)} \\
& +Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)} \\
& -Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)}
\end{aligned}
$$

by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)} \\
& +Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The convergence of (62) is guaranteed by the convergence of (56) (where the third line follows a similar argument in the proof of Theorem 3.4 (3) using $D$-conjugation property). The convergence of (63) follows from the convergence of vertex operator since both $Y^{-}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)}$

and $Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)}$ contains finitely many terms. Therefore, (61) converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. So the part in (57) contributed by (59) converges.

To discuss the contribution of (60) in (57), we first compute the sum of (60) over $n \geq 1$ as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{n \geq 1} \sum_{m \geq 0} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m-n-\alpha} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m-n-\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) z_{p+1}^{-m-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \sum_{n \geq 1} \sum_{m+n+\alpha \geq 0}\binom{m+n+\alpha}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) z_{p+1}^{-m-n-\alpha-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \sum_{m \geq-\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) \sum_{n \geq 1}(-1)^{\alpha}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} z_{p+1}^{-m-n-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty} \sum_{m \leq-\alpha-1}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) \sum_{n \geq-m-\alpha}(-1)^{\alpha}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} z_{p+1}^{-m-n-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{\alpha}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} \sum_{m \geq-\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) z_{p+1}^{-m-1}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{\alpha}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} \sum_{m \leq-\alpha-1}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) z_{p+1}^{\alpha} z_{p+2}^{-m-\alpha-1}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

So the contribution of (60) in (57) is given by the contribution of (64) and (65). Clearly, (64) contains only finitely many terms. So the convergence of its contribution in (57) follows from the convergence of products of vertex operators. For (65), note that it differs to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{\alpha}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} \sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right) z_{p+1}^{\alpha} z_{p+2}^{-m-\alpha-1}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{\alpha}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha}\left(Y\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right)+Y_{1}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right)\right) a^{(k)} z_{p+1}^{\alpha} z_{p+2}^{-\alpha}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

by finitely many terms. We then use the the existence of (56) to conclude that the action of $Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right)$ ) on (66) converges. So the contribution of (65) in (57) also converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function.

- We now study (58). From the definition,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)}=\sum_{m, n \geq 1}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} a_{-n}^{(j)} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
= & \sum_{m, n \geq 1} \frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{-m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m-n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
& +\sum_{m, n \geq 1} a_{-n}^{(j)} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0}\binom{-m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{-m-1-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(k)}\right)_{-m-1-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
= & \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \sum_{n \geq 1} \sum_{m-n-\alpha \geq 1} \frac{1}{2}\binom{-m+n+\alpha}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-n-\alpha-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
& +Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \sum_{m \geq \alpha+2} \frac{1}{2}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} \cdot \sum_{n=1}^{m-\alpha-1} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} z_{p+1}^{m-n-1} z_{p+2}^{n-1} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right)\left(e^{z_{p+1} D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(k)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(i)}-Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)}\right) \\
= & \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \sum_{m \geq \alpha+2} \frac{1}{2}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} \cdot \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} \frac{z_{p+1}^{m-1}-z_{p+1}^{\alpha} z_{p+2}^{m-\alpha-1}}{z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) e^{z_{p+1} D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(k)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(i)}-\frac{1}{2} Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)}\right) \\
= & \frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha}\left(\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-1}\right)\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} z_{p+1}^{\alpha} z_{p+2}^{-\alpha}\left(\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+2}^{m-1}\right) \cdot\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha}\left(\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m} ^{d e f} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-1}\right)\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{p+1}}\right)^{\alpha} z_{p+1}^{\alpha} z_{p+2}^{-\alpha}\left(\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m} ^{d e f} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+2}^{m-1}\right) \cdot\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) e^{z_{p+1} D} Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(k)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(i)}-\frac{1}{2} Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We first analyze the part in (58) contributed by (67). First note that the summation of $\alpha$ in (67) is finite. For each $\alpha \geq 0$, by the convergence of products of $Y$-operator,

$$
\begin{gathered}
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}, z_{p+1}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
=\sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right)\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-1}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1}
\end{gathered}
$$

converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. The same holds if we remove the finitely many parts with $m<\alpha+2$. Apply the partial derivatives with the coefficients, and sum up those finitely many $\alpha$ 's, we conclude the part in (58) contributed by (67) converges. Similarly, we prove that the part in (58) contributed by (68) also converges. For the part in (58) contributed by (69), the only difference is that we start with the series

$$
\begin{gathered}
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}, z_{p+1}\right) a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1} \\
=\sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right)\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} a_{-1}^{(k)} \mathbf{1} z_{p+1}^{m-1}\left(z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right)^{-1}
\end{gathered}
$$

the convergence of which follows from the minimal weight assumption and the convergence of (56). Similarly, we prove that the part in (58) contributed by (70) also converges. Finally, for the part in (58) contributed by (71), we use Theorem 3.4 (3) to see that

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) a^{(k)}
$$

and

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(k)},-z_{p+1}\right) a^{(i)}
$$

Removing finitely many terms, we may replace the $Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right)$ by its regular part $Y^{+}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{p+2}\right)$. Then with an argument similar to that in the proof of Theorem 3.4 (3), we conclude that the part in (58) contributed by (71) also converges. Therefore, (58) converges. Once we established the convergence for $j \leq k$, the case $j>k$ follows easily from an analytic continuation argument. From what is shown above,

$$
E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}\right) Y\left(a^{(k)}, z_{p+2}\right) a^{(j)}\right)
$$

exists. By skew-symmetry and $D$-conjugation formula,

$$
E\left(e^{z_{p+2} D} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}-z_{p+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(p)}, z_{p}-z_{p+2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{p+1}-z_{p+2}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)},-z_{p+2}\right) a^{(k)}\right)
$$

exists. Since $e^{z_{p+2} D}$ does not interfere with the convergence, with a change of variable, we see that (55) exists.

Remark 4.9. As pointed in Section 3.3.2, this convergence guarantees that for every $i_{1}, i_{2}, i_{3}, j \in$ $\{1, \ldots, r\}$ such that $a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}$ and $a^{(j)}$ are of minimal weight, the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) a^{(j)}\right)
$$

is well-defined. This is the starting point of the cocycle equation with one additional variable in Section 3.3.3.
4.5. Iterates. In order to check the condition of Lemma 4.3 in the inductive step, we also need the following result.

Lemma 4.10. Assume that for $i, j=1, \ldots, r, v, w \in V$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right) \\
=E\left(Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right) \\
E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right) \\
=E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) w\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(v, z_{3}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(v, z_{3}\right) w\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{3}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{3}\right) w\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

then for every $p \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w\right)\right. \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. We first proceed to understand the $Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right)$ in the first two lines of (75). Substitute $z_{1} \mapsto x_{1}$ in (73), take $\operatorname{Res}_{x_{1}=z_{2}}\left(x_{1}-z_{2}\right)^{-p}$ and rearrange the terms, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w \\
= & \operatorname{Res}_{x_{1}=z_{2}}\left(x_{1}-z_{2}\right)^{-p} E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w+Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) w-Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) w\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Together with a similar expression of $Y\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right)$, we see that a sufficient condition for (75) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right)-E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) w\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right) \\
& -E\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

From commutatitivity of the vertex operator $Y$, the terms with negative signs, namely,

$$
E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) w\right) \text { and } E\left(Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right)
$$

are equal and thus can be both removed. We then use associativity to rewrite the iterate $Y\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}-z_{2}\right) v, z_{2}\right)$ as a product $Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right)$, use commutativity of $Y$-operator to rearrange the ordering, finally moving terms around, to rewrite the identity as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right)-E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right) \\
= & E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right) \\
& -E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

From (74), the left-hand-side is precisely

$$
E\left(Y\left(a^{(j)}, x_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(v, z_{2}\right) w\right)
$$

The identity then follows from (72). So we proved the first equality of (75). The second equality follows from a similar argument as in Corollary 4.7 and shall not be repeated here.

Lemma 4.11. With the notations and assumptions in Lemma 4.10, for every $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v\right)_{n}\right] w+\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right] w} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a_{-p}^{(j)} v\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a_{-p}^{(j)} v\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) w
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Essentially this is an argument by Jacobi identity. More precisely, for every fixed $v^{\prime} \in V^{\prime}$, from $(75)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle v^{\prime}, Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w+Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w\right\rangle\right. \\
& \left\langle v^{\prime}, Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w+Y\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) w\right\rangle \\
& \left\langle v^{\prime}, Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w+Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}-z_{2}\right) a_{-p}^{(j)} v, z_{2}\right) w\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

are the expansion of a common rational function (with poles at $z_{1}=0, z_{2}=0$ and $z_{1}=z_{2}$ ) respectively in the regions $\left|z_{1}\right|>\left|z_{2}\right|>0,\left|z_{2}\right|>\left|z_{1}\right|>0,\left|z_{2}\right|>\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|>0$. Using the same arguments as in Proposition 2.3.26 in [LL], we obtain a Jacobi-like identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{0}^{-1} \delta\left(\frac{x_{1}-x_{2}}{x_{0}}\right)\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x_{1}\right) Y\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, x_{2}\right) w+Y\left(a^{(i)}, x_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, x_{2}\right) w\right) \\
& +x_{0}^{-1} \delta\left(\frac{-x_{2}+x_{1}}{x_{0}}\right)\left(Y_{1}\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, x_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, x_{1}\right) w+Y\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} v, x_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x_{1}\right) w\right) \\
& =x_{2}^{-1} \delta\left(\frac{x_{1}-x_{0}}{x_{2}}\right)\left(Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, x_{0}\right) a_{-p}^{(j)} v, x_{2}\right) w+Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, x_{0}\right) a_{-p}^{(j)} v, x_{2}\right) w\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Formula (76) directly follows from applying $\operatorname{Res}_{x_{0}} \operatorname{Res}_{x_{1}} x_{1}^{m} \operatorname{Res}_{x_{1}} x_{2}^{n}$.
Remark 4.12. As an immediate application of Lemma 4.10, we may conclude that for $i, j, k \in$ $\{1, \ldots, r\}$ of minimal weight and every $m \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left(a_{-p}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{n}\right] \mathbf{1}+\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(\left(a_{-p}^{(j)}\right)^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)_{n}\right] \mathbf{1}} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a_{-p}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a_{-p}^{(j)} a^{(k)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

In case $a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}, a^{(k)}$ are chosen such that for $\alpha \geq 0 a_{\alpha}^{(j)} a^{(k)}$ and $\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}$ involves elements of the form $a_{-q_{1}}^{(p_{1})} a_{-q_{2}}^{(p_{2})} \mathbf{1}$, we will need this commutator formula to prove Proposition 4.6 and Corollary 4.7.

# 5. Particular solution: the inductive step 

In this section, with the results proved in Section 4, we formulate the main theorem and provide the proof of the inductive step.

# 5.1. Main theorem and its induction hypothesis. 

Theorem 5.1. For every $q, n \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(q)} \in S, v \in V, i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1} \in\{1, \ldots, r\}$, the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right)
$$

exists, and the following variant of the multivariable cocycle equation holds

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds. In other words, the $Y_{1}$-operator constructed in Section 4.1 is a particular solution for the cocycle equation in Section 3.

Remark 5.2. With an argument using skew-symmetry, $D$-conjugation formula and a change of variable, we see that the equation $(78)+(79)=(80)+(81)$ is equivalent to the cocycle equation $(27)+(28)=(29)+(30)$ in Section 3 (with $\left.s^{(j)} \mapsto a^{\left(i_{j}\right)}\right)$. Details are very similar to those in Corollary 4.7 and are thus omitted here.

We will argue by induction on the sum of weights of $a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, \ldots a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}$ and the number of variables $n$. More precisely, we fix $p, N \in \mathbb{N}$, and assume that the conclusions of Theorem 5.1 hold for every $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and every $i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1}$ satisfying

$$
\text { wt } a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}+\cdots+\text { wt } a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}<N
$$

Assume also that the conclusions hold for every $n<p$ and $i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1}$ satisfying

$$
\text { wt } a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}+\cdots+\text { wt } a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}=N
$$

We will proceed to show that the same holds $n=p$.
5.2. Consequences of the induction hypothesis. The induction hypothesis implies the following lemmas.

Lemma 5.3. With $n, i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1}$ as in the induction hypothesis, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}\right)_{q_{1}} ^{d e f} \cdot a_{q_{2}}^{(i_{2})}\right] a_{-q_{3}}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-q_{p}}^{(i_{p})} \mathbf{1}+\left[a_{q_{1}}^{(i_{1})},\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}\right)_{q_{2}} ^{d e f}\right] a_{-q_{3}}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p+1}\right)}^{(i_{p+1} 1} \mathbf{1} } \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{q_{1}}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}\right)_{q_{1}+q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{\left(i_{1}\right)} a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}\right)_{q_{1}+q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-q_{3}}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p+1}\right)}^{(i_{p+1} 1} \mathbf{1}\right. \\
\text { for every } & q_{1}, q_{2} \in \mathbb{Z}, q_{3}, \ldots, q_{p+1} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Using the $D$-conjugation property and a change of variables, we see that we may replace the $a^{\left(i_{p+1}\right)}$ at the end of $(78)-(81)$ by $Y\left(a^{\left(i_{p+1}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}$. We then apply $\operatorname{Res}_{z_{3}=0} z_{3}^{-q_{3}} \cdots \operatorname{Res}_{z_{p+1}=0} z_{p+1}^{-q_{p+1}}$ to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) a_{-\left(q_{3}\right.}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{p+1}\right)}^{(i_{p+1})} \mathbf{1}\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) a_{-\left(q_{3}\right.}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{p+1}\right)}^{(i_{p+1})} \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) a_{-\left(q_{3}\right.}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{p+1}\right)}^{(i_{p+1})} \mathbf{1}\right)+E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) a_{-\left(q_{3}\right.}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{p+1}\right)}^{(i_{p+1})} \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The conclusion follows from an argument similar to those in Corollary 4.7 and Lemma 4.11.
Lemma 5.4. With $n, i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1}$ as in the induction hypothesis, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left[\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left(a_{-\left(q_{2}\right.}^{(i_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1})} \mathbf{1}\right)_{n}\right]+\left[\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}\right)_{m},\left(a_{-\left(q_{2}\right.}^{(i_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1})} \mathbf{1}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right]\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a_{-\left(q_{2}\right.}^{(i_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1})} \mathbf{1}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{\left(i_{1}\right)} a_{-\left(q_{2}\right.}^{(i_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1})} \mathbf{1}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1}\right. \\
& \text { holds for every } m, n \in \mathbb{Z}, l=2, \ldots, n+1, q_{2}, \ldots, q_{n+1} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. From the induction hypothesis,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l}\right)}, z_{l}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)}, z_{l+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l}\right)}, z_{l}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)}, z_{l+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l}\right)}, z_{l}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)}, z_{l+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l}\right)}, z_{l}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)}, z_{l+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}, z_{n+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds. Supplement a $Y(\mathbf{1}, \zeta)$ between $Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{l}\right)$ and $Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)}, z_{l+1}\right)$, apply
$\operatorname{Res}_{z_{l+1}=0} z_{l+1}^{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.} \cdots \operatorname{Res}_{z_{n+1}=0} z_{n+1}^{-q_{n+1}}$, and use associativity of the $Y$-operator, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l}\right)}, z_{l}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l}\right)}, z_{l}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{3}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{l}\right)}, z_{l}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Apply $\operatorname{Res}_{z_{3}=\zeta}\left(z_{3}-\zeta\right)^{-q_{3}} \cdots \operatorname{Res}_{z_{l}=\zeta}\left(z_{l}-\zeta\right)^{-q_{l}}$, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a_{-\left(q_{3}\right.}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1}\right)} \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1}\right)\right. \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a_{-\left(q_{3}\right.}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1}\right)} \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a_{-\left(q_{3}\right.}^{(i_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{1}\right.}^{(i_{1}\right)} \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) a_{-\left(q_{l+1}\right.}^{(i_{l+1})} \cdots a_{-\left(q_{n+1}\right)}^{(i_{n+1})} \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
+E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a_{-\left(i_{3}\right.}^{\left(i_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{l}\right)}^{\left(i_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) a_{-\left(i_{l+1}\right)}^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{n+1}\right)}^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)
$$

So the third condition in Lemma 4.10 holds. The other two can be checked with a similar process. Then Lemma 4.11 applies, giving the identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left[\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left(a_{-\left(i_{2}\right)}^{\left(i_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{l}\right)}^{\left(i_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{n}\right]+\left[a_{m}^{\left(i_{1}\right)},\left(a_{-\left(i_{2}\right)}^{\left(i_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{l}\right)}^{\left(i_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{n}^{\text {def }}\right]\right) a_{-\left(i_{l+1}\right)}^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{n+1}\right)}^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a_{-\left(i_{2}\right)}^{\left(i_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{l}\right)}^{\left(i_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{\left(i_{1}\right)} a_{-\left(i_{2}\right)}^{\left(i_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{l}\right)}^{\left(i_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\left(i_{l+1}\right)}^{\left(i_{l+1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left(i_{n+1}\right)}^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma 5.5. With $n, i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$as in the induction hypothesis, for each $q \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(q)} \in$ $S, r=1, \ldots, n, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{r} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$, the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r}\right)}, z_{q+r}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r+1}\right)}, z_{q+r+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

is well-defined and independent of the choice of $\zeta$, and the following equation of $\bar{V}$-valued rational functions holds:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r}\right)}, z_{q+r}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r+1}\right)}, z_{q+r+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r}\right)}, z_{q+r}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r+1}\right)}, z_{q+r+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right) \\
& =E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{q+2}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r}\right)}, z_{q+r}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r+1}\right)}, z_{q+r+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y_{1}\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{q+2}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r}\right)}, z_{q+r}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r+1}\right)}, z_{q+r+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. When $r=2$, the convergence of (85) and (86) is automatic. The convergence of (84) follows from the convergence of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) e^{\zeta D} Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{3}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)},-\zeta\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad \cdot Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}-\zeta\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{q+2}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which follows from associativity, skew-symmetry, $D$-conjugation property and an argument of analytic continuation. Thus from the cocycle equation $(78)+(79)=(80)+(81)$ together with an argument of analytic continuation, we see that (83) converges, and $(83)+(84)=(85)+(86)$. Assume the conclusion holds for every smaller $r$, then the convergence of (85) and (86) follows from the induction hypothesis. The convergence of (84) follows from the convergence of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) e^{\zeta D} Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r+1}\right)}, z_{q+r+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)},-\zeta\right) \\
& \quad \cdot Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(i_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}-\zeta\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{2}\right)}, z_{q+2}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r}\right)}, z_{q+r}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which follows from associativity, skew-symmetry, $D$-conjugation property and an argument of analytic continuation. Thus from the cocycle equation $(78)+(79)=(80)+(81)$ together with an argument of analytic continuation, we see that (83) converges, and $(83)+(84)=(85)+(86)$.

Lemma 5.6. With $n, i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$as in the induction hypothesis, for each $q \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(q)} \in$ $S, r=1, \ldots, n, m_{1}, \ldots, m_{r} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$, the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a_{-\left.m_{1}\right|}^{\left.i_{1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.m_{r}\right|}^{\left.i_{r}\right)} \mathbf{1}, z_{q+r}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(i_{r+1}\right)}, z_{q+r+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(i_{n}\right)}, z_{q+n}\right) a^{\left(i_{n+1}\right)}\right)
$$

is well-defined.
Proof.
