The conclusion follows from evaluating $\zeta=z_{q+r}$ in (82), then applying the residue operation $\operatorname{Res}_{z_{q+r}=0} z_{q+r}^{-m_{r}} \operatorname{Res}_{z_{q+r-1}=z_{q+r}}\left(z_{q+r-1}-z_{q+r}\right)^{-m_{r-1}} \cdots \operatorname{Res}_{z_{q+1}=z_{q+r}}\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+r}\right)^{-m_{1}}$.
5.3. Commutator formula: general case. We now carry out the proof of the induction step. For the convenience of notations, we will replace $i_{1}, \ldots, i_{n+1}$ in (77) - (81) by $i, j_{1}, \ldots, j_{p}$.

Proposition 5.7. Fix $i \in\{1, \ldots, r\}, 1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{p} \leq r$ with

$$
\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+\cdots+\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}=N
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{2}\right|}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right|}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}+\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right] a_{-\left.q_{2}\right|}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right|}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\left.q_{2}\right|}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right|}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

holds for every $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}$.
Proof. In case $m, n<0$, or $m \geq 0, n<0$, or $m<0, n \geq 0$, (87) follows from a similar argument as Proposition 4.4. We focus on the case $m \geq 0, n \geq 0$. First,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a_{-\left.q_{2}\right|}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right|}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
= & \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}\left[a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, a_{-\left.q_{2}\right|}^{(j_{2})} a_{-\left.q_{3}\right|}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right|}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}+\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{-\left.q_{2}\right|}^{(j_{2})} a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a_{-\left.q_{3}\right|}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right|}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

It is clear that $a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a_{-q_{3}}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-q_{p}}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ is a linear combination of elements of whose filtration is strictly less than wt $a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+$ wt $a^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots+$ wt $a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}$. From Lemma 5.3, we may rewrite $\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a_{-q_{2}}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-q_{p}}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}\left[a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, a_{-q_{2}}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right] a_{-q_{3}}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-q_{p}}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\left(a_{-q_{2}}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}+\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)}-a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}\right) a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a_{-q_{3}}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-q_{p}}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a_{-q_{3}}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-q_{p}}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

We also use Lemma 5.3 to rewrite $a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a_{-q_{2}}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\left(a_{-q_{2}}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}+\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)}-a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the first commutator $\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ may be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}\left[a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\left[a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}+\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)}-a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left[\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Unraveling the commutators and recombine, we see that the first commutator $\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left(a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right]+a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{(j)}\right]\right) a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\left(\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)} a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}-a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{q_{2}}^{d e f}-a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)}\right) a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left[\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we compute the second commutator. By definition, we may express $a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f} a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}+a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}-a_{m}^{(i)} a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha} a_{m}^{(i)}\left(\left(\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Also by definition, we may express $\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ as

$$
\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}+\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f} a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}
$$

Clearly, $a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}$ is a linear combination of elements whose filtration is strictly less than wt $a^{(i)}+$ wt $a^{(j_{3})}+\cdots+$ wt $a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}$. We use Lemma 5.3 to rewrite it as

$$
\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{-\left.q_{2}\right)}^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right] a_{-\left.q_{3}\right)}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\left.q_{p}\right)}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +\left(a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2}}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}+\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}-\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}\right) a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j_{1})} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the second commutator $\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)^{d e f}\right] a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}$ may be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\right] a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}+\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{n}^{(j_{1})}-a_{n}^{(j_{1})}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}\right] a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j_{1})} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right] a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Unraveling the commutators and recombine, we see that the second commutator $\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)^{d e f}\right] a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}$ is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(-\left[\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f},\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\right]\right]+a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right]\right) a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\left(a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2}} a_{m}^{(i)} a_{n}^{(j_{1})}-a_{m}^{(i)} a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})} a_{n}^{(j_{1})}-a_{n}^{(j_{1})}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f} a_{m}^{(i)}+a_{n}^{(j_{1})} a_{m}^{(i)}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-q_{2}}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{n}{\alpha}\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(j_{1})} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{n-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}\right] a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining (88), (89) and reorganize, we see that the left-hand-side of (87) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left[a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\right]\right]+\left[\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f},\left[a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2}}, a_{m}^{(i)}\right]\right]+\left[\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f},\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right]\right]\right) a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\left(a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right]+a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right]\right) a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left[\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}, a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})}\right] a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

If we apply Lemma 5.3 on (90), and combine it with the right-hand-side of (87), we see that the identity (87) is equivalent to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left[a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\right]\right]+\left[\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f},\left[a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2}}, a_{m}^{(i)}\right]\right]+\left[\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{-n}^{d e f},\left[a_{m}^{(i)}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right]\right]\right) a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left[a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})},\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right]+a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{2})}\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right]\right] a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1} \\
& +\sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left[\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)_{m-q_{2}-\alpha}^{d e f}, a_{-\alpha_{3}}^{(j_{3})}\right] a_{-\alpha_{2}}^{(j_{3})} \cdots a_{-\alpha_{p}}^{(j_{p})} \mathbf{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

The conclusion then follows from Lemma 4.1 and Lemma 4.3, provided that the three conditions of Lemma 4.3 holds. We check the condition of Lemma 4.3 with $u=a^{(i)}$ and $v=a_{\alpha}^{(j_{1})} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}$.

Since $\alpha \geq 0$, we see that $a_{\alpha}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}$ is a linear combination of $a_{-\mathrm{f}_{1}}^{\left(k_{1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\mathrm{f}_{l}}^{\left(k_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}$, with

$$
\text { wt } a^{\left(k_{1}\right)}+\cdots+\text { wt } a^{\left(k_{l}\right)}<\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}
$$

Then we apply Lemma 5.4 to conclude that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f},\left(a_{-\mathrm{f}_{1}}^{\left(k_{1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\mathrm{f}_{l}}^{\left(k_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{n}\right]+\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a_{-\mathrm{f}_{1}}^{\left(k_{1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\mathrm{f}_{l}}^{\left(k_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right]\right) a_{-\mathrm{q}_{3}}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\mathrm{q}_{p}}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a_{-\mathrm{f}_{1}}^{\left(k_{1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\mathrm{f}_{l}}^{\left(k_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a_{-\mathrm{f}_{2}}^{\left(k_{1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\mathrm{f}_{l}}^{\left(k_{l}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f}\right) a_{-\mathrm{q}_{3}}^{\left(j_{3}\right)} \cdots a_{-\mathrm{q}_{p}}^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \mathbf{1}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

So we checked the condition of Lemma 4.3 for each component of $a_{\alpha}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}$. Combining these component together, we see that the condition of Lemma 4.3 holds for $(u, v)=\left(a^{(i)}, a_{\alpha}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}\right)$. With a similar process, we check the other two conditions of Lemma 4.3 with $(u, v)=\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, a_{\alpha}^{\left(j_{2}\right)} a^{(i)}\right)$ and $(u, v)=\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)$, to conclude the proof.

# 5.4. Proof of the cocycle equation. 

Proposition 5.8. Fix $i \in\{1, \ldots, r\}, 1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{p} \leq r$ with

$$
\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+\cdots+\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}=N
$$

Then for every $\alpha=1, \ldots, p$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. When $\alpha=1$, from Proposition 5.7, using a similar argument as Propostion 4.6 and Corollary 4.7, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the induction hypothesis, we may remove the positive sign on top and prove the identity.

With $\alpha=1$ case clear, we may use it to see that for $\alpha \geq 2$ and $i \leq j_{1}$, the identity directly holds. In what follows, we assume that $i>j_{1}$. We focus on (93). By commutativity of the $Y$-operator, we may arrange $Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right)$ in an appropriate location and use the conclusion from $\alpha=1$. So it is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
= & E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& -E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Combine the last line with (94) and use induction hypothesis, we see that $(93)+(94)$ is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}

Apply commutativity on Line 3, and use the induction hypothesis on the sum of Line 1 and Line 3 , we see that $(93)+(94)$ is equal to

& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\

& +E\left(Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\
& +E\left(Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{2}\right) Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha}\right)}, z_{\alpha+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha-1}\right)}, z_{\alpha}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{\alpha+1}\right)}, z_{\alpha+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}, z_{p+1}\right) \mathbf{1}\right) \\

From commutativity, Line 1 coincides with (91). For Line 2, 3 and 4, we use commutativity to move $Y\left(a^{(i)}, z_{1}\right)$ to the front and apply induction hypothesis, to see that they are equal to (92). So we proved that $(93)+(94)=(91)+(92)$.

Remark 5.9. Proposition 5.8 essentially proves the cocycle equation $(78)+(79)=(80)+(81)$ in Theorem 5.1. Indeed, from commutativity of the $Y$-operator, we may assume that $i_{3} \leq \cdots \leq$ $i_{n+1}$. Proposition 5.8 basically states that the equation holds no matter how $i_{1}$ and $i_{2}$ are chosen.

Remark 5.10. Together with Theorem 3.7 and a similar residue argument, it is straightforward to show that the extended $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow V((x))$ given in the proof Theorem 3.7 satisfies the cocycle equation (6). We shall omit the details here.

Remark 5.11. The reader might be tempted to use Dong-Li Lemma (Proposition 5.5.15 in [LL], see also [L2]) to bypass the technicalities. However, our attempt showed that this approach has various conceptual and technical difficulties. The application of Dong-Li Lemma to first-order deformations requires substantial modifications that might not be a lot easier than the above.

# 5.5. Proof of the convergence. 

Proposition 5.12. Fix $i \in\{1, \ldots, r\}, 1 \leq j_{1} \leq \cdots \leq j_{p} \leq r$ with

$$
\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+\cdots+\text { wt } a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}=N
$$

Then for every $q \in \mathbb{N}, s^{(1)}, \ldots, s^{(q)} \in S$, the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}\right)
$$

Proof. The base case has been proved in Proposition 4.8. Its proof shows that we may also assume the convergence of

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}
$$

and

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}
$$

in the induction hypothesis. Now we proceed with the inductive step.
We first note that from the induction hypothesis, the series

$$
Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}
$$

converges to a $\bar{V}$-valued rational function. exists. Indeed, we may use the commutator formula of the $Y$-operator to see that the series is the sum of

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{\alpha \geq 0} & \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{q+1}}\right)^{\alpha} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) \\
& \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a_{\alpha}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a^{\left(j_{k}\right)}, z_{q+k}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+k}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the sum over $\alpha$ is indeed finite, and for each $\alpha \geq 0, a_{\alpha}^{\left(j_{1}\right)} a^{\left(j_{k}\right)}$ is a linear combination of $a_{-\overline{m_{1}}}^{\left(l_{1}\right)} \cdots a_{-\overline{m_{n}}}^{\left(l_{n}\right)} \mathbf{1}$, with $\mathrm{wt} a^{\left(l_{1}\right)}+\cdots+\mathrm{wt} a^{\left(l_{n}\right)}<\mathrm{wt} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}+\mathrm{wt} a^{\left(j_{k}\right)}$. Therefore, from associativity and the induction hypothesis, we know that the series

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) \\
& \quad \cdot Y\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y\left(Y\left(a^{\left(l_{1}\right)}, \zeta_{1}-z_{q+k}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(l_{n}\right)}, \zeta_{n}-z_{q+k}\right) \mathbf{1}, z_{q+k}\right) \\
& \quad \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+k}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

converges. Taking an appropriate residue, sum over the finite linear combination, finally sum over the finitely many $\alpha$ 's, we see that (98) converges.

Thus, in order to prove the existence of (95), it suffices to show the convergence of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) Y\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \\
= & Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \\
& +Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) Y^{-}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We note that (100) differs from the convergent series

by

which is also convergent by a similar argument with (98). For (99), we repeat the splitting process similarly and reduce the discussion of convergence to the series

by

& +\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{q+1}}\right)^{\alpha} z_{q+1}^{\alpha} z_{q+2}^{-\alpha}\left(\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m} z_{q+2}^{m-1}\right) \cdot\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& \cdot Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{q+1}}\right)^{\alpha}\left(\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} z_{q+1}^{m-1}\right)\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& \cdot Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{\alpha}}{\alpha!}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z_{q+1}}\right)^{\alpha} z_{q+1}^{\alpha} z_{q+2}^{-\alpha}\left(\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} z_{q+2}^{m-1}\right) \cdot\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& \cdot Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)} \\
& +Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) Y_{1}^{+}\left(a^{(i)}, z_{q+1}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the sum over $\alpha$ in (112) - (115) are all finite. Likewise, we analyze the contribution of each part in (102)

- For the contribution of (112) in (102), we start with the series $\frac{1}{2} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+2}\right)^{-1}$
for each $\alpha$, which converges because of the convergence of products of $Y$-operators, together with a reduction process similar to those from (98) to (101). Separate

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}\right)= & Y^{-}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}\right)+\sum_{0 \leq m<\alpha+2}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m} z_{q+1}^{m-1} \\
& +\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m} z_{q+1}^{m-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

The $Y^{-}$-part contribution in (117) converges by the commutator formula of $Y$ and a reduction process. For each $m$, the contribution of $\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m} z_{q+1}^{m-1}$ in (117) may be expressed

as a residue of the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function given by (117), thus also converges. So

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) \sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m}\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& \cdot Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

also converges. Apply appropriate coefficients and partial derivatives, then sum over the finitely many $\alpha$ 's, we see that the contribution of (112) in (102) converges.

- For the contribution of (113) in (102), its convergence is similarly shown as that of (112). We shall not repeat the details here.
- For the contribution of (114) in (102), we start with the series
$\frac{1}{2} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) Y_{1}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right) Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+2}\right)^{-1}$
for each $\alpha \geq 0$. Note that $a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}$ has its filtration index strictly less than wt $a^{(i)}+$ wt $a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}-1$. Thus from Lemma 5.6 together with a reduction process similar to those from (98) to (101), we see that (118) converges. Separate

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{1}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}\right)= & Y_{1}^{-}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+1}\right)+\sum_{0 \leq m<\alpha+2}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} z_{q+1}^{m-1} \\
& +\sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f} z_{q+1}^{m-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

The $Y_{1}^{-}$-part contribution in (118) converges by the induction hypothesis and a reduction process. For each $m$, the contribution of $\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m} z_{q+1}^{m-1}$ in (118) may be expressed as a residue of the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function given by (118), thus also converges. So

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2} Y\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(q)}, z_{q}\right) \sum_{m \geq \alpha+2}\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}\right)_{-m}^{d e f}\left(z_{q+1}-z_{q+2}\right)^{-1} \\
& \cdot Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{2}\right)}, z_{q+3}\right) \cdots Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{p-1}\right)}, z_{q+p}\right) a^{\left(j_{p}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

also converges. Apply appropriate coefficients and partial derivatives, then sum over the finitely many $\alpha$ 's, we see that the contribution of (114) in (102) converges.

- For the contribution of (115) in (102), its convergence is similarly shown as that of (114). We shall not repeat the details here.
- For the contribution of (116) in (102), its convergence is similarly shown as that of (103), by moving the operator $Y^{+}\left(a^{\left(j_{1}\right)}, z_{q+2}\right)$ to the front via commutator formula of the $Y$-operator, then apply the induction hypothesis. We shall not repeat the details here.
5.6. Summary and remarks. Collecting the results in Section 3, 4 and 5, we have proved the following theorem:

Theorem 5.13. The cohomology classes in $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ are represented by the union of the finite set

$$
\left\{M_{m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right): 0 \leq m<\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(j)}-1, a^{(i)}, a^{(j)} \in S, 1 \leq i \leq j \leq r\right\}
$$

of elements in $V$, and the finite set

$$
\left\{B\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right): a^{(i)}, a^{(j)} \in S, 1 \leq i \leq j \leq r\right\}
$$

of complex numbers, such that with the notation

$$
\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(j)}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
M_{m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) & \text { if } i \leq j, 0 \leq m<\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(j)}-1 \\
\sum_{\alpha \geq 0}(-1)^{m+\alpha+1} \frac{D^{\alpha}}{\alpha!} M_{m+\alpha}\left(a^{(j)}, a^{(i)}\right) & \text { if } i>j, 0 \leq m<\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(j)}-1 \\
B\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right) \mathbf{1} & \text { if } i \leq j, m=\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(j)}-1 \\
(-1)^{\text {wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(i)}} B\left(a^{(j)}, a^{(i)}\right) \mathbf{1} & \text { if } i>j, m=\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(j)}-1 \\
0 & \text { if } m>\text { wt } a^{(i)}+\text { wt } a^{(j)}-1
\end{array}\right.
$$

the commutator condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f}, a_{n}^{(j)}\right] a^{(k)}+\left[a_{m}^{(i)},\left(a^{(j)}\right)_{n}^{d e f}\right] a^{(k)}} \\
= & \sum_{\alpha=0}^{\infty}\binom{m}{\alpha}\left(\left(\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha} a^{(k)}+\left(a_{\alpha}^{(i)} a^{(j)}\right)_{m+n-\alpha}^{d e f} a^{(k)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds for every $1 \leq i, j, k \leq r, m, n \in \mathbb{N}$.
To summarize the long process in proving Theorem 5.13, we started from a cocycle $\Phi$ and set

$$
Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z\right) a^{(j)}=\Phi\left(a^{(i)} \otimes a^{(j)} ; z, 0\right)=\sum_{m \in \mathbb{Z}}\left(a^{(i)}\right)_{m}^{d e f} a^{(j)} z^{-m-1}
$$

for each $1 \leq i, j \leq r$. Theorem 3.4 shows that we may pick $Y_{1}$ such that its regular part is completely determined by its singular part. Proposition 3.6 gives an explicit formula

$$
M_{-m}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{\alpha \geq 0} \frac{D^{m+\alpha}}{(m+\alpha)!}\binom{-m}{\alpha} M_{\alpha}\left(a^{(i)}, a^{(j)}\right)
$$

To study $Y_{1}(u, x) v$, we took an approach via generating functions and studied the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function

$$
E\left(Y_{1}\left(s^{(1)}, z_{1}\right) Y\left(s^{(2)}, z_{2}\right) \cdots Y\left(s^{(n)}, z_{n}\right) s^{(n+1)}\right)
$$

Propostion 4.8 and the subsequent Theorem 5.1 showed that the (119) is well-defined. Section 3.3.3 formulated the cocycle equation (119) should satisfy. Theorem 3.10 showed that the complementary solutions of the cocycle equation are all coboundaries. We then construct (119) via the modes of $Y_{1}$ in Section 4.1. Theorem 5.1 proves that the so-constructed (119) satisfy the cocycle equation. Theorem 3.7 shows (119) determines $Y_{1}(u, x) v$ for generic $u, v \in V$. Remark 5.10 explains how to show the cocycle equation holds for generic $u, v \in V$.

Remark 5.14. The construction in Section 4.1 and the conclusion of Theorem 5.1 do not essentially depend on the freely generated assumption on $V$. For a general vertex algebra $V$, starting from $Y_{1}: S \otimes S \rightarrow V((x))$, we may follow the same process to extend it to $Y_{1}: V \otimes V \rightarrow$ $V((x))$ and make sure that $Y_{1}$ sends the singular vectors to zero. The only problem is that the so-constructed $Y_{1}$ is only a particular solution of the cocycle equation. There might be other cocycles from the complementary solution that is nontrivial in $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$. Besides, we have to make sure that after carrying out the extension process, $Y_{1}$ should send singular vectors to zero. This implies additional constraints on the choice of $Y_{1}^{-}\left(a^{(i)}, x\right) a^{(j)}$.

Recall that in [H1], based on the different convergence requirements, there are different versions of cohomology theories. In [H2], it is shown that the first cohomology does not essentially depend on these convergence conditions. We now show that the same holds for the second cohomology of freely generated vertex algebras.

Theorem 5.15. If $V$ is a freely generated vertex algebra, then $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V) \simeq H_{\infty}^{2}(V, V)$.
Proof. From Theorem 5.1 and Lemma 5.5, by taking an appropriate residue, we see that for every $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{l}, v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}, w_{1}, \ldots, w_{n} \in V$, the $\bar{V}$-valued rational function
$E\left(Y\left(u_{1}, z_{1}\right) \cdots Y\left(u_{l}, z_{l}\right) Y_{1}\left(Y\left(v_{1}, z_{l+1}-\zeta\right) \cdots Y\left(v_{l+m}, z_{l+m}-\zeta\right) \mathbf{1}, \zeta\right) Y\left(w_{1}, z_{l+m+1}\right) \cdots Y\left(w_{n}, z_{l+m+n}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)$
is well-defined. This in turn shows that every representative of $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$ is indeed composable with infinitely many vertex operators (see [H1], [H2] and [Q2] for formal definitions). Let $K_{\infty}$ and $B_{\infty}$ respectively be the spaces of cocycles and coboundaries that are composable with infinitely many vertex operators. Let $K_{1 / 2}$ and $B_{1 / 2}$ respectively be the spaces of cocycles and coboundaries satisfying the $1 / 2$-composable condition in [H2]. What we have proved is that

$$
K_{1 / 2} / B_{1 / 2}=\left(K_{\infty}+B_{1 / 2}\right) / B_{1 / 2}=\left(K_{\infty}+B_{1 / 2}\right) / B_{\infty} / B_{1 / 2} / B_{\infty}
$$

From the second isomorphism theorem, we conclude that

$$
K_{1 / 2} / B_{1 / 2} \simeq K_{\infty} / B_{\infty} /\left(K_{\infty} \cap B_{1 / 2}\right) / B_{\infty} \simeq K_{\infty} / B_{\infty}
$$

since $K_{\infty} \cap B_{1 / 2}=B_{\infty}$. The conclusion then follows.

# 6. EXAMPLES 

Summarizing the results from Section $3-5$, we see that to determine $H_{1 / 2}^{2}(V, V)$, it suffices to classify $Y_{1}\left(a^{(i)}, z\right) a^{(j)}$ containing only the singular parts, and the components satisfy the commutator condition (44) in Section 4.2. Once we classify such $Y_{1}$, it remains to check if some of them are given by a coboundary. We shall carry out this procedure for the following class of examples.

6.1. Universal Virasoro VOA. Recall that the universal Virasoro VOA $\operatorname{Vir}_{c}$ is generated by the conformal element $\omega$. We set

$$
Y_{1}(\omega, x) \omega=a_{(0)} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}+a_{(1)} \omega x^{-2}+a_{(2)} D \omega x^{-1}+Y_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) \omega
$$

Skew-symmetry specifies that

$$
a_{(1)}=2 a_{(2)}
$$

The commutator condition does not impose further relations. If we choose

$$
\phi(\mathbf{1})=0, \phi(\omega)=a_{(2)} \omega
$$

and for all other basis element $v$,

$$
\phi(v)=0
$$

Then

$$
Y_{1}(\omega, x) \omega-Y_{\phi}(\omega, x) \omega=a_{(0)} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}+\text { regular }
$$

Clearly, the map $\omega \otimes \omega \mapsto a_{(0)} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}$ satisfies the commutator condition and thus extends to a cocycle. Thus

$$
Y_{1}(\omega, x) \omega-Y_{\phi}(\omega, x) \omega-a_{(0)} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}
$$

is a regular cocycle. From Proposition 3.1, we see that (120) is represented by a coboundary. Thus we conclude that

$$
\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(\operatorname{Vir}_{c}, \operatorname{Vir}_{c}\right)=1
$$

6.2. Universal affine VOA. Let $\mathfrak{g}$ be a simple Lie algebra. Recall that the universal affine VOA $V^{l}(\mathfrak{g})$ is generated by $\mathfrak{g}$ that is identified with the weight-1 subspace. Let $e_{1}, \ldots, e_{r}$ be a basis of $\mathfrak{g}$. Then for every $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r$,

$$
Y_{1}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}=B\left(e_{i}, e_{j}\right) \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+M\left(e_{i}, e_{j}\right) x^{-1}
$$

Generally, for $a, b \in \mathfrak{g}$

$$
Y_{1}(a, x) b=B(a, b) \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+M(a, b) x^{-1}+\text { regular part. }
$$

The skew-symmetry of $Y_{1}$ requires that

$$
B(a, b)=B(b, a), M(a, b)=-M(b, a)
$$

The commutator condition (44) requires that for every $a, b, c \in \mathfrak{g}$,

$$
B([a, b], c)+l\langle M(a, b), c\rangle=B(a,[b, c])+l\langle a, M(b, c)\rangle
$$

and

$$
M([a, b], c)+M([b, c], a)+M([c, a], b)+[M(a, b), c]+[M(b, c), a]+M([c, a], b)=0
$$

(121) and (123) implies that $M$ is a cocycle in the Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain complex. Since $H^{2}(\mathfrak{g})=0$, there exists $f: \mathfrak{g} \rightarrow \mathfrak{g}$ such that

$$
M(a, b)=[a, f(b)]-f([a, b])+[f(a), b]
$$

Plug (124) into (122), and set $a=x_{\alpha}, b=h, c=x_{\beta}$, where $\alpha, \beta$ are roots for $\mathfrak{g}, h$ is an element in the Cartan subalgebra of $\mathfrak{g}$, we obtain that

$$
-\alpha(h)\left(B\left(x_{\alpha}, x_{\beta}\right)-l\left\langle f\left(x_{\alpha}\right), x_{\beta}\right\rangle-l\left\langle x_{\alpha}, f\left(x_{\beta}\right)\right)=\beta(h)\left(B\left(x_{\alpha}, x_{\beta}\right)-l\left\langle f\left(x_{\alpha}\right), x_{\beta}\right\rangle-l\left\langle x_{\alpha}, f\left(x_{\beta}\right)\right)\right.\right.
$$

Therefore, if $\alpha+\beta \neq 0$, then

$$
B\left(x_{\alpha}, x_{\beta}\right)-l\left\langle f\left(x_{\alpha}\right), x_{\beta}\right\rangle-l\left\langle x_{\alpha}, f\left(x_{\beta}\right)\right\rangle=0
$$

Plug (124) into (122), and set $a=h, b=x_{\alpha}, c=x_{-\alpha}$, we see that

$$
\alpha(h)\left(B\left(x_{\alpha}, x_{-\alpha}\right)-l\left\langle x_{\alpha}, f\left(x_{-\alpha}\right)\right\rangle-l\left\langle x_{-\alpha}, f\left(x_{\alpha}\right)\right\rangle\right)=B\left(h, h_{\alpha}\right)-l\left\langle h, f\left(h_{\alpha}\right)\right\rangle-l\left\langle f(h), h_{\alpha}\right\rangle
$$

holds for every $h$ in the Cartan subalgebra. If $\alpha$ is simple, and $h=h_{\beta}$ is the root vector for another simple root $\beta$, then since $\alpha\left(h_{\beta}\right)=\left\langle h_{\alpha}, h_{\beta}\right\rangle \neq 0$, we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
B\left(x_{\alpha}, x_{-\alpha}\right)-l\left\langle x_{\alpha}, f\left(x_{-\alpha}\right)\right\rangle-l\left\langle x_{-\alpha}, f\left(x_{\alpha}\right)\right\rangle & =\frac{1}{\left\langle h_{\alpha}, h_{\beta}\right\rangle}\left(B\left(h_{\beta}, h_{\alpha}\right)-l\left\langle h_{\beta}, f\left(h_{\alpha}\right)\right\rangle-l\left\langle f\left(h_{\beta}\right), h_{\alpha}\right\rangle\right) \\
& =B\left(x_{\beta}, x_{-\beta}\right)-l\left\langle x_{\beta}, f\left(x_{-\beta}\right)\right\rangle-l\left\langle x_{-\beta}, f\left(x_{\beta}\right)\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

If we set

$$
B_{\mathfrak{g}}=B\left(x_{\alpha}, x_{-\alpha}\right)-l\left\langle x_{\alpha}, f\left(x_{-\alpha}\right)\right\rangle-l\left\langle x_{-\alpha}, f\left(x_{\alpha}\right)\right\rangle
$$

then $B_{\mathfrak{g}}$ is a constant for every simple root $\alpha$. Now for a generic root $\beta$, there exists a simple root $\alpha$ with $\left\langle h_{\alpha}, h_{\beta}\right\rangle \neq 0$. Applying the same argument, we see that $B_{\mathfrak{g}}$ is a constant for every root $\alpha$. So the notation is justified. It is straightforward to check that for every $a, b \in \mathfrak{g}$,

$$
B(a, b)-l\langle f(a), b\rangle-l\langle a, f(b)\rangle=\langle a, b\rangle B_{\mathfrak{g}}
$$

We construct $\phi: V \rightarrow V$ by

$$
\phi(a(-m) \mathbf{1})=(f(a))(-m) \mathbf{1}
$$

and for every other basis element of $V$,

$$
\phi(v)=0
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{\phi}(a, x) b= & Y(f(a), x) b-\phi\left(Y^{-}(a, x) b\right)+Y(a, x) f(b) \\
= & l\langle f(a), b\rangle \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+[f(a), b] x^{-1}+f([a, b]) x^{-1} \\
& +l\langle a, f(b)\rangle \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+[a, f(b)] x^{-1}+Y^{+}(f(a), b)+Y^{+}(a, x) f(b) \\
= & (l\langle f(a), b\rangle+l\langle a, f(b)\rangle) \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+([f(a), b]-f([a, b])+[a, f(b)]) x^{-1} \\
& +Y^{+}(f(a), b)+Y^{+}(a, x) f(b) \\
= & \left(B(a, b)+\langle a, b\rangle B_{\mathfrak{g}}\right) \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+M(a, b) x^{-1}+Y^{+}(f(a), x) b+Y^{+}(a, x) f(b)
\end{aligned}
$$

In other words,

$$
Y_{1}(a, x) b-Y_{\phi}(a, x) b-\langle a, b\rangle B_{\mathfrak{g}} \mathbf{1} x^{-2}
$$

contains only the regular part. Clearly, the map $a \otimes b \mapsto\langle a, b\rangle B_{\mathfrak{g}} \mathbf{1}$ satisfies the commutator condition and thus extends to a cocycle. So (125) gives rise to a regular cocycle. From Proposition 3.1, we see that (125) is represented by a coboundary. Thus $Y_{1}(a, x) b-\langle a, b\rangle B_{\mathfrak{g}} \mathbf{1} x^{-2}$ is a coboundary. So we conclude that for every $l \in \mathbb{C}$,

$$
\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(V^{l}(\mathfrak{g}), V^{l}(\mathfrak{g})\right)=1
$$

Remark 6.1. The results in Section 6.1 and 6.2 basically implies that aside from the deformation perturbing the central charge $c$ of $\operatorname{Vir}_{c}$ (the level $l$ of $V^{l}(\mathfrak{g})$, respectively), no other deformation can possibly exist.
6.3. Heisenberg VOA. Let $\mathfrak{h}$ be a finite-dimensional abelian Lie algebra with a nondegenerate bilinear form $\langle\cdot, \cdot\rangle$. Recall that the Heisenberg VOA $V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})$ is generated by $\mathfrak{h}$ that is identified with weight-1 subspace. Let $e_{1}, \ldots, e_{r}$ be an orthonormal basis of $\mathfrak{h}$. Then for every $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r$,

$$
Y_{1}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}=a_{i j} \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+\sum_{k=1}^{r} M_{i j}^{k} e_{k}(-1) \mathbf{1} x^{-1}
$$

and

$$
Y_{1}\left(e_{j}, x\right) e_{i}=a_{j i} \mathbf{1} x^{-2}+\sum_{k=1}^{r} M_{j i}^{k} e_{k}(-1) \mathbf{1} x^{-1}+\sum_{m \geq 2} \sum_{k=1}^{r} M_{j i}^{k} e_{k}(-m) \mathbf{1} x^{m-2}
$$

The skew-symmetry requires that

$$
a_{i j}=a_{j i}, M_{i j}^{k}=-M_{j i}^{k}
$$

The commutator condition (44) requires that for every $1 \leq i, j, k \leq r$,

$$
l M_{i j}^{k}=l M_{j k}^{i}=l M_{k i}^{j}
$$

(127) and (128) are the only requirement of $a_{i j}$ and $M_{i j}^{k}$ to be a cocycle. We shall proceed to find the coboundaries.

- In case $l \neq 0$, we set for each $i=1, \ldots, r$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \phi\left(e_{i}(-m) \mathbf{1}\right)=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{i \alpha}}{2 l} e_{\alpha}(-m) \mathbf{1}, m \geq 1 \\
& \phi\left(e_{i}\left(-m_{1}\right) e_{i}\left(-m_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{i \alpha}}{2 l}\left(e_{i}\left(-m_{1}\right) e_{\alpha}\left(-m_{2}\right)+e_{\alpha}\left(-m_{1}\right) e_{i}\left(-m_{2}\right)\right) \mathbf{1}, m_{1} \geq m_{2} \geq 1
\end{aligned}
$$

for each $1 \leq i<j \leq r$,

$$
\phi\left(e_{i}\left(-m_{1}\right) e_{j}\left(-m_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}\right)=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{i \alpha}}{2 l} e_{\alpha}\left(-m_{1}\right) e_{j}\left(-m_{2}\right) \mathbf{1}+\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{\alpha j}}{2 l} e_{i}\left(-m_{1}\right) e_{\alpha}\left(-m_{2}\right), m_{1}, m_{2} \geq 1
$$

and for other basis element $v \in V$,

$$
\phi(v)=0
$$

Then for every $1 \leq i \leq j \leq r$

$$
Y_{\phi}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}=Y\left(\phi\left(e_{i}\right), x\right) e_{j}-\phi\left(\sum_{m \geq 1} e_{i}(-m) e_{j}(-1) \mathbf{1}\right) x^{m-1}+Y\left(e_{i}, x\right) \phi\left(e_{j}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{i \alpha}}{2 l}\left(Y\left(e_{\alpha}, x\right) e_{j}-Y^{+}\left(e_{\alpha}, x\right) e_{j}\right)+\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{\alpha j}}{2 l}\left(-Y^{+}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{\alpha}+Y\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{\alpha}\right) \\
& =\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{i \alpha}}{2 l}\left(l \cdot \delta_{\alpha j} \mathbf{1} x^{-2}\right)+\sum_{\alpha=1}^{r} \frac{a_{\alpha j}}{2 l}\left(l \cdot \delta_{i \alpha} \mathbf{1} x^{-2}\right)=a_{i j} \mathbf{1} x^{-2}
\end{aligned}
$$

So

$$
Y_{1}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}-Y_{\phi}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}=\sum_{k=1}^{r} M_{i j}^{k} e_{k}(-1) \mathbf{1} x^{-1}
$$

Note also that for any homogeneous map $\psi: V \rightarrow V$, the coefficient of $x^{-1}$ of the series

$$
Y_{\psi}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}=Y\left(\psi\left(e_{i}\right), x\right) e_{j}-\psi\left(Y\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}\right)+Y\left(e_{i}, x\right) \psi\left(e_{j}\right)
$$

is constantly zero. Therefore, it is impossible to further reduce the right-hand-side of (129) via coboundaries. So $H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(V^{l}(\mathfrak{h}), V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})\right)$ is in one-to-one correspondence with the space of structural constants

$$
\left\{M_{i j}^{k} \in \mathbb{C}: M_{i j}^{k}=M_{j k}^{i}=M_{k i}^{j}, M_{i j}^{k}=-M_{j i}^{k}, i, j, k=1, \ldots, r\right\}
$$

As a result, we conclude that

$$
\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(V^{l}(\mathfrak{h}), V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})\right)=\binom{r}{3} \text { if } l \neq 0
$$

- In case $l=0$, we see that (128) degenerates to a trivial relation. We also see that for any homogeneous map $\psi: V \rightarrow V$, the coefficient of $x^{-2}$ and $x^{-1}$ of the series $Y_{\psi}\left(e_{i}, x\right) e_{j}$ is constantly zero. Therefore, other than the constraint (127), it is impossible to further reduce the right-handside of (126). So $H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(V^{l}(\mathfrak{h}), V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})\right)$ is in one-to-one correspondence with $a_{i j}$ and $M_{i j}^{k}$ satisfying (127). We conclude that

$$
\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(V^{l}(\mathfrak{h}), V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})\right)=\binom{r}{2}+\binom{r}{2} \cdot r=3\binom{r+1}{3} \text { if } l=0
$$

Remark 6.2. If the map $M$ satisfies the Jacobi identity, then $(\mathfrak{h}, M)$ forms a quadratic Lie algebra with respect to the bilinear form on $\mathfrak{h}$ (see, for example, [HK]. In that case, $V^{l}(\mathfrak{h})$ deforms to an affine VOA. This is analogous to the classical fact that the universal enveloping algebra $U(\mathfrak{g})$ is a deformation of the symmetric algebra $S(\mathfrak{g})$.
6.4. Universal Zamolodchikov algebra $W_{3}^{c}$. The universal Zamolodchikov algebra $W_{3}^{c}$ is a vertex algebra freely generated by two fields $\omega$ and $W$, with

$$
\begin{gathered}
\omega_{3} \omega=\frac{c}{2} \mathbf{1}, \omega_{2} \omega=0, \omega_{1} \omega=2 \omega, \omega_{0} \omega=D \omega \\
\omega_{1} W=3 W, \omega_{0} W=D W
\end{gathered}
$$

and

$$
\begin{gathered}
W_{5} W=\frac{c}{3} \mathbf{1}, W_{4} W=0, W_{3} W=2 \omega, W_{2} W=D \omega \\
W_{1} W=\frac{32}{22+5 c} \omega_{-1} \omega+\frac{3(-2+c)}{2(22+5 c)} D^{2} \omega, W_{0} W=\frac{32}{22+5 c} \omega_{-2} \omega+\frac{-2+c}{3(22+5 c)} D^{3} \omega
\end{gathered}
$$

when $c \neq-22 / 5$. When $c=22 / 5$, (130) is modified as

$$
W_{1} W=32 \omega_{-1} \omega-\frac{48}{5} D^{2} \omega, W_{0} W=32 \omega_{-2} \omega-\frac{32}{15} D^{3} \omega
$$

(see $[\mathrm{Z}]$ and $[\mathrm{AL}]$ ). We now determine $H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(W_{3}^{c}, W_{3}^{c}\right)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{1}(\omega, x) \omega= & a_{(0)}^{\omega} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}+a_{(2)}^{\omega} \omega x^{-2}+\left(a_{(3,1)}^{\omega} D \omega+a_{(3,2)}^{\omega} W\right) x^{-1}+Y_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) \omega \\
Y_{1}(\omega, x) W= & a_{(0)} \mathbf{1} x^{-5}+a_{(2)} \omega x^{-3}+\left(a_{(3,1)} D \omega+a_{(3,2)} W\right) x^{-2} \\
& +\left(a_{(4,1)} D^{2} \omega+a_{(4,2)} \omega_{-1} \omega+a_{(4,3)} D W\right) x^{-1} \\
Y_{1}(W, x) W= & a_{(0)}^{W} \mathbf{1} x^{-6}+a_{(2)}^{W} \omega x^{-4}+\left(a_{(3,1)}^{W} D \omega+a_{(3,2)}^{W} W\right) x^{-3} \\
& +\left(a_{(4,1)}^{W} D^{2} \omega+a_{(4,2)}^{W} \omega_{-1} \omega+a_{(4,3)}^{W} D W\right) x^{-2} \\
& +\left(a_{(5,1)}^{W} D^{3} \omega+a_{(5,2)}^{W} \omega_{-2} \omega+a_{(5,3)}^{W} D^{2} W+a_{(5,4)}^{W} \omega_{-1} W\right) x^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

The commutator condition (44) with $u=v=w=\omega$ implies that

$$
a_{(3)}^{\omega}=\frac{a_{(2)}^{\omega}}{2}, a_{(3,2)}^{\omega}=0
$$

- If $c \neq-22 / 5$, then the commutator condition (44) with $u=v=\omega, w=W$ implies that

$$
a_{(0)}=\frac{c}{2} a_{(2)}, a_{(3,1)}=a_{(4,1)}=a_{(4,2)}=0, a_{(4,3)}=\frac{a_{(2)}^{\omega}}{2}
$$

The commutator condition (44) with $u=\omega, v=w=W$ and with $u=v=w=W$ implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{(0)}^{\omega}=\frac{2+c}{6} a_{(3,2)}+\frac{22+5 c}{3} a_{(4,1)}^{W}, a_{(2)}^{\omega}=\frac{2}{3} a_{(3,2)} \\
& a_{(0)}^{W}=\frac{44+42 c}{9(22+5 c)} a_{(3,2)}+\frac{4(11+5 c)}{9} a_{(4,1)}^{W}, a_{(2)}^{W}=\frac{64}{3(22+5 c)} a_{(3,2)}+\frac{20}{3} a_{(4,1)}^{W} \\
& a_{(3,1)}^{W}=\frac{32}{3(22+5 c)} a_{(3,2)}+\frac{10}{3} a_{(4,1)}^{W}, a_{(3,2)}^{W}=\frac{114+7 c}{48} a_{(5,4)}^{W}, a_{(4,2)}^{W}=0, a_{(4,3)}^{W}=a_{(2)}+\frac{114+7 c}{96} a_{(5,4)}^{W} \\
& a_{(5,1)}^{W}=-\frac{8}{9(22+5 c)} a_{(3,2)}+\frac{2}{9} a_{(4,1)}^{W}, a_{(5,2)}^{W}=0, a_{(5,3)}^{W}=\frac{1}{2} a_{(2)}+\frac{6+c}{48} a_{(5,4)}^{W}
\end{aligned}
$$

The only free variables are $a_{(2)}, a_{(3,2)}$, and $a_{(4,1)}^{W}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{1}(\omega, x) \omega= & a_{(3,2)}\left(\frac{2+c}{6} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}+\frac{2}{3} \omega x^{-2}+\frac{1}{3} D \omega x^{-1}\right)+a_{(4,1)}^{W}\left(\frac{22+5 c}{3} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}\right)+Y_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) \omega \\
Y_{1}(\omega, x) W= & a_{(2)}\left(\frac{c}{2} \mathbf{1} x^{-5}+\omega x^{-3}\right)+a_{(3,2)} W x^{-2}+a_{(3,2)} D W x^{-1}+Y_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) W \\
Y_{1}(W, x) W= & a_{(2)}\left(D W x^{-2}+\frac{1}{2} D^{2} W x^{-1}\right) \\
& +a_{(3,2)}\left(\frac{2(22+21 c)}{9(22+5 c)} \mathbf{1} x^{-6}+\frac{64}{3(22+5 c)} \omega x^{-4}+\frac{32}{3(22+5 c)} D \omega x^{-3}-\frac{8}{9(22+5 c)} D^{3} \omega x^{-1}\right) \\
& +a_{(4,1)}^{W}\left(\frac{4}{9}(11+5 c) \mathbf{1} x^{-6}+\frac{20}{3} \omega x^{-4}+\frac{10}{3} D \omega x^{-3}+D^{2} \omega x^{-2}+\frac{2}{9} D^{3} \omega x^{-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

- In case $c \neq 2$, we set

$$
\phi(\omega)=\frac{1}{3} a_{(3,2)} \omega, \phi(W)=\frac{2(22+5 c)}{3(c-2)} a_{(4,1)}^{W} W+\frac{1}{4} a_{(2)} D \omega, \phi\left(\omega_{-1} \omega\right)=\frac{2}{3} a_{(3,2)} \omega_{-1} \omega
$$

so that $\phi\left(\omega_{-m} \omega_{-n} \mathbf{1}\right)$ is uniquely determined for every $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$by $D$-derivative property. We further set

$$
\phi(v)=0
$$

for every other basis element $v$. We see that $Y_{1}-Y_{\phi}$ is proportional to the map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(\omega, x) \omega= & \frac{1}{6} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}+\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) \omega \\
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(\omega, x) W= & \widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) W \\
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(W, x) W= & \frac{2(21 c+22)}{9(c-2)(5 c+22)} \mathbf{1} x^{-6}-\frac{2(5 c+54)}{3(c-2)(5 c+22)} \omega x^{-4}-\frac{(5 c+54)}{3(c-2)(5 c+22)} D \omega x^{-3} \\
& -\left(\frac{64}{3(c-2)(5 c+22)} \omega_{-1} \omega+\frac{1}{2(5 c+22)} D^{2} \omega\right) x^{-2} \\
& -\left(\frac{64}{3(c-2)(5 c+22)} \omega_{-2} \omega+\frac{1}{9(5 c+22)} D^{3} \omega\right) x^{-1}+\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(W, x) W
\end{aligned}
$$

We check that $\bar{Y}_{1}$ satisfy the commutator condition. We conclude that $\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(W_{3}^{c}, W_{3}^{c}\right)=1$ when $c \neq 2$ and $c \neq-22 / 5$.

- In case $c=2$, we set

$$
\phi(\omega)=\frac{1}{3} a_{(3,2)} \omega, \phi(W)=\frac{1}{3} a_{(3,2)} W+\frac{1}{4} a_{(2)} D \omega, \phi\left(\omega_{-1} \omega\right)=\frac{2}{3} a_{(3,2)} \omega_{-1} \omega
$$

so that $\phi\left(\omega_{-m} \omega_{-n} \mathbf{1}\right)$ is uniquely determined for every $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$by $D$-derivative property. We further set

$$
\phi(v)=0
$$

for every other basis element $v$. We see that $Y_{1}-Y_{\phi}$ is proportional to the map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(\omega, x) \omega & =\frac{32}{3} \mathbf{1} x^{-4}+\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) \omega \\
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(\omega, x) W & =\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) W \\
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(W, x) W & =\frac{28}{3} \mathbf{1} x^{-6}+\frac{20}{3} \omega x^{-4}+\frac{10}{3} D \omega x^{-3}+D^{2} \omega x^{-2}+\frac{2}{9} D^{3} \omega x^{-1}+\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(W, x) W
\end{aligned}
$$

We check that $\bar{Y}_{1}$ satisfy the commutator condition. Thus we conclude that $\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(W_{3}^{c}, W_{3}^{c}\right)=$ 1 when $c=2$.

- If $c=-22 / 5$, then with a similar procedure, we find that $Y_{1}$ is represented by the following map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(\omega, x) \omega & =3 \cdot \mathbf{1} x^{-4}+\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) \omega \\
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(\omega, x) W & =\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(\omega, x) W \\
\widetilde{Y}_{1}(W, x) W & =-44 \cdot \mathbf{1} x^{-6}+60 \omega x^{-4}+30 D \omega x^{-3}+9 D^{2} \omega x^{-2}+2 D^{3} \omega x^{-1}+\widetilde{Y}_{1}^{+}(W, x) W
\end{aligned}
$$

We conclude that $\operatorname{dim} H_{1 / 2}^{2}\left(W_{3}^{c}, W_{3}^{c}\right)=1$ when $c=-22 / 5$.

abstract:
We solve the problem of how to classify the first-order vertex-algebraic
deformations for any grading-restricted vertex algebra $V$ that is freely
generated by homogeneous elements of positive weights. We approach by computing
the second cohomology $H^2_{1/2}(V, V)$ constructed by Yi-Zhi Huang. We start
with the cocycle on two generators and show that its cohomology class is
completely determined by its singular part. To extend the cocycle to any pair
of elements in $V$, we take a generating function approach, formulate the
cocycle equation, and show that all the complementary solutions are
coboundaries. Then we use a very general procedure to construct a particular
solution. The procedure applies to vertex algebras that are not freely
generated. As a by-product, we show that $H^2_{1/2}(V, V) = H^2_\infty(V, V)$.
Using these results, we explicitly determine the first-order deformations of
the universal Virasoro VOA $Vir_c$, universal affine VOA $V^l(\mathfrak{g})$,
Heisenberg VOA $V^l(\mathfrak{h})$, and the universal Zamolodchikov VOA
$W_3^c$.
